Some of the contracts last two or three years, meaning payments could continue for some time.“As highlighted on many occasions, all commitments taken by the 28 Member States should be honoured by the 28 Member States,” A statement released by the European Commission said.“This is also true in a ‘no-deal’ scenario, where the UK would be expected to continue to honour all commitments made during EU membership.”The statement continues: “Today’s proposal enables the EU to be in a position, in a ‘no-deal’ scenario, to honour its commitments and to continue making payments in 2019 to UK beneficiaries for contracts signed and decisions made before 30 March 2019, on condition that the UK honours its obligations under the 2019 budget and that it accepts the necessary audit checks and controls.EU takes less than 10 minutes to reject MPs’ demand to bin backstop“This would help mitigate the significant impact of a “no-deal” scenario for a wide range of areas that receive EU funding, such as research, innovation or agriculture.&nbsp“This issue is separate from and without prejudice to the financial settlement between the EU and the United Kingdom in a no-deal scenario.”Officials admit they cannot force the UK to make any payments once it has left the bloc, though they hope Britain&nbspwill take up the offer.Though the EU has ruled out doing ‘side deals’ with the UK to soften a no-deal Brexit, the move on the budget contributions suggests the commitment is open to interpretation.&nbspThe Commission says its no-deal planning “cannot replicate the withdrawal agreement”, is “unilateral” and is aimed at mitigating the “most disruptive effect on EU27 stakeholders”. It has stepped up preparations in recent weeks and months, with 88 stakeholder notices and 18 legislative proposals.What just happened with Brexit- and what happens next?EU would rather no-deal Brexit than abandon Irish backstop, May toldMay wins backing to renegotiate backstop but EU says noOn Wednesday it also unveiled measures to protect the Erasmus international study programme, confirming that it would honour the overseas placements of UK and EU27 students who were abroad at the time of a no-deal. This commitment affects around 7,000 UK nationals on the continent and 14,000 EU nationals in the UK.Former Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said last year that “the Government would not pay the terms of the financial settlement, as agreed with the EU as part of the withdrawal agreement” in the event of a no-deal, because&nbsp”there’s no deal without the whole deal”. It is not clear whether the Government’s policy has shifted since Mr Raab’s departure, however, with the issue of the orce bill falling off the agenda and the focus moving to Northern Ireland.In September Theresa May said “the position changes” on the issue of the payments if the UK left without a deal: leaving herself room for manoeuvre.The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsFollow the latest on&nbspextreme weather in&nbspthe United StatesClick to followThe Independent USParts of America are&nbspfacing&nbsptemperatures colder than Antarctica this week, as a cold front sweeps through the upper midwest.US officials are urging residents from northern states to stay inside as the deep freeze sets in across the county, bringing with it life-threatening conditions.A blast of Arctic air from the polar vortex&nbspis causing temperatures&nbspto drop as low as -40C (-40F), and in some cases even colder.For exclusive articles, events and an advertising-free read for just Start your free trialWith an Independent Minds subscription for just Start your free trialWithout the ads – for justStart your free trialFollow live updates on the weather across the states belowTemperatures in the United States are shockingly cold today, but one city so far has claimed today's record in Minnesota.&nbspNorris Camp in Minnesota saw temperatures drop for three hours to -44C (-48F), with a wind chill bringing the temperatures down to -54C (-68F).&nbspThat is the coldest temperature so far recorded in the lower 48 states and colder than Alaska's North Slope.The cold in Chicago has been accompanied by some power outages, according to local power suppliers.&nbspAround 9,300 customers were reportedly without power, primarily in the city's suburbs, as of Wednesday afternoon.The National Weather Services in Iowa is warning against being, well, chill during the chill.&nbspHere's a bit from a release from the organization. Stay warm, Iowa.&nbspTHIS HAS THE POTENTIAL TO BE LIFE-THREATENING COLD AIR!!!This is the coldest air many of us will have ever experienced. Thisis not a case of meh, it`s Iowa during winter and this coldhappens. These are record-breaking cold air temperatures, with windchill values not seen in the 21st century in Iowa.Here's the latest on temperatures from around the country, from news wire services:&nbspTemperatures in parts of the Northern Plains and Great Lakes plunged to as low minus 42 Fahrenheit (minus 41 Celsius) in Park Rapids, Minnesota, and minus 31F in Fargo, North Dakota, according to the National Weather Service. The frigid winds were bound for the U.S. East Coast later on Wednesday into Thursday.Here's some footage from North Dakota and Minnesota during an arctic blast that made the roads appear white.Conditions in the American midwest are so cold that officials have warned against breathing too deeply outside, or even talking much while outside.&nbspIt could be, for some generations in the midwest, the first time that this amount of cold has been felt, AccuWeater meteorologist Mike Doll told USA Today:&nbsp“Some locations in the Midwest will be below zero continuously for 48-72 hours,” he saidBut the worst is yet to come, Doll said. “I cannot stress how dangerously cold it will be,” he said. “An entire generation has gone by without experiencing this type of cold.”Please allow a moment for the liveblog to loadOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: national living wage uk budget 2018 increase minimum wage 16 18 25 year olds
story: But Chancellor Philip Hammond has announced a further increase for some workers from  - heres what you need to know.The National Living Wage is the amount of money all employees aged over  are legally entitled to.It used to be known as the National Minimum Wage, but it was re-branded in .The National Living Wage increased from £. to £. for those aged  and over.The  pence-an-hour rise was introduced on Sunday April , .The compulsory National Living Wage was introduced in .The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.In Budget , Chancellor Hammond announced that lowest-paid workers will get another pay rise from next year to a minimum of £. per hour.Its a five per cent hike, which will come into force from April, and will benefit around .million workers.Mr Hammond said: From April [the National Living Wage] will rise again, handing a full-time worker a £ annual pay increase.Hammond is aiming to get the wage to £ by .It is dferent to the real living wage which is voluntary and not fixed by the government.The National Minimum Wage is the amount workers aged under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.However, the amount dfers depending on age and whether the worker is on an apprenticeship scheme.From April  the rate for National Living Wage and National Minimum Wage is:From April  the rate for National Living Wage and National Minimum Wage will be:The national limits are legally binding.Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to title: theresa may customs union tory dup backstop
story: The PM’s stand comes as her pact with her Northern Irish allies hung by a thread after extraordinary revelations DUP chiefs want her gone by Christmas and deputy leader Nigel Dodds mocked Tory panic.And in fresh headache for Mrs May it was also emerged last night the EU are secretly discussing extending the Brexit process because of the chaos.Her tough words came in a bid to quell the revolt over the so called Brexit backstop - which Brexiteers insist must have “get out clause” written into it. The “backstop” would see Britain mirror EU rules indefinitelyno new trade deal is in place to keep the Northern Irish border open.The EU now suggests a longer post-Brexit transition until December , citing lack of progress. It would see us paying Brussels billions extra.But Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab insisted that it must be “time-limited” and cannot leave Britain “in definite limbo”.However he stopped short of demanding a named date as Brussels has rejected this and Downing Street said his stance was consistent with the PM.No said the PM would never agree to a deal which would trap the UK in a backstop permanently.” But Ireland said having an open ended backstop was “a deal-breaker” for them.Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney said: “The backstop needs to be there unless and until something better comes along. Nobody wants to use the backstop - this is like taking out fire insurance on your house.”But yesterday Philip Hammond explicitly stated the temporary period would be needed to be invoked.Mrs May has always insisted the backstop is unlikely to ever be needed, yet Mr Hammond said: “It is true that there needs to be a period - probably following the transition period that weve negotiated and before we enter into our long-term partnership.Mrs May now heads to Brussels on Wednesday to meet fellow EU leaders for a crunch summit that faces deadlock.Meanwhile open civil war broke out between Tory MPs and their crucial DUP allies over the issue, after the Northern Irish threatened to dethrone the PM.And as Sun columnist James Forsyth reveals today, some senior figures in the DUP want the PM to be ousted within weeks.Tory MP Nick Boles hit out: “Conservative leaders are chosen by Conservative MPs and Conservative Party members. Not by MPs of any other party. And we respond no better to threats than proud Ulster men or women do.And it emerged Eurocrats are mulling plans to prolong the transition period in a bid to stop the DUP torpedoing a Brexit deal.Sources said the withdrawal pact could be changed so the  month window can be extended to reassure Unionists the backstop will never be needed.The EU is making a demand of Theresa May she cannot fulfil without national humiliation, mass Cabinet resignations and near-certain Commons defeat.Brussels must know it is utterly unreasonable to demand we stay locked in their customs union indefinitely. Or that they should dictate when we can finally leave. Which they never would.A .million majority voted to leave. MPs voted that meant leaving the customs union. Our democracy, sovereignty and trading future are all at stake. Mrs May must defend all three. God knows what happens next weekshe doesn’t.The Remain ultras should be loving this chaos. Except they have suffered their own disaster. The EU sayswe held a second referendum and voted Remain, they’d strip us of our historic rebate on payments to Brussels.So along with violent unrest, a ­collapse of trust in democracy and a huge surge in extremism, Remaining would come with a whole new price tag on top of EU membership fees: Four thousand million quid a year.Good luck selling that.But the plot will enrage Brexiteers, who fear efforts to trap Britain permanently in the Single Market and Customs Union as a vassal state.During a transition the UK will be banned from striking trade deals and will have to keep making budget payments, while following EU rules without any say.Sources said Michel Barnier is considering a new plan that would see the transition stay in place until the end of  - meaning a two year, nine month phase.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: john bercow out of parliament tories replace him
story: Today the chairman of the Tory Buckingham association is meeting the Conservative party’s national head of candidate selection Gareth Fox to find a suitable figure to fight the seat.He wants the party to start advertising the position from today.The Speaker has stood unopposed in his Buckingham seat since standing down as a Tory MP in  to take the neutral role of Speaker.But the Tories are hoping he will quit before the next election to free up the seat.The move will put pressure on Mr Bercow amid the outrage over claims he is helping Remainer MPs thwart Brexit in the Commons.When he was elected in  Mr Bercow had pledged to only serve until  but has cited the uncertainty over Brexit to justy staying on.It was understood he would only extend his tenure until June this year but Tories now fear he will use the deepening Brexit crisis to cling on longer and even beyond the next General Electiona snap vote is called.But that would be the fourth General Election in a row at which the Buckingham seat is left uncontested.Buckingham Tory association chairman Cllr Clive Harriss said anger was rising among constituents over their lack of a choice for MP at elections.He said the party would traditionally only start looking for a new candidate when the Speaker stands down.But he told The Sun: “We’ve started to put feelers out with a view we’ll have someone in place soan election is calledhe decides not to stand we’ll have someone in place to fight the seat in the normal way.“I’ll be talking to central office on Friday to make sure they advertise the position.”However he admitted the party has “absolutely no influence” over when Mr Bercow decides to stand down.Mr Harriss added: “We don’t know what’s going to happenthere is a General Election.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chavez socialist experiment venezuela opinion
story: GDP growth will stall. Taxes will rise. We’ll even run out of Mars bars.But across the Atlantic, something has been ­happening that should give us all some perspective.Over the past decade, Venezuela has plunged into the abyss — but there’s been no civil war, no earthquakes or hurricanes.Just a brutal, corrupt government that has turned what was once Latin America’s richest country into a hellhole.Starvation rations plunged millions into hunger and ­malnutrition, with some resorting to eating dogs, cats, even zoo animals.People got into kne fights over the right to scavenge from a dumpster.Its economy is more than three times smaller than in . Inflation climbed into the thousands, then millions of per cent.The result has been a refugee crisis on the scale of the Syria conflict.No wonder tens of ­thousands of people took to the streets of the capital Caracas this week, declaring national assembly head Juan Guaido the legitimate president.All this is awful for the poor bloody Venezuelans.But what does it have to do with Britain The answer is that Venezuela wasn’t just a ­disaster. It was an experiment — cheered on by Jeremy Corbyn and his cronies.In , Hugo Chavez took over Venezuela.He ruled until his death in , when he was succeeded by his hand-picked protege Nicolas Maduro.Chavez modelled himself on Latin American ­revolutionaries like Fidel Castro and Simon Boli. He nationalised much of the oil industry — which dominates the ­Venezuelan economy — and imposed punitive taxes on foreign firms.He introduced price controls and later currency controls. He declared “economic war” on the “stateless ­bourgeoisie” and seized the goods of private companies he denounced as saboteurs.For Corbyn, the Chavez regime was an inspiration — a chance to see true socialism brought to le.Venezuela, Corbyn has said, “showed us that there is a dferent, and a better, way of doing things. It’s called socialism”.It wasn’t just Corbyn. Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell, Shadow Home Secretary Diane Abbott and Corbyn’s media chief Seumas Milne have all praised the ­Venezuelan revolution.That “better way of doing things” has ruined tens of millions of lives but there has not been a hint of an apology from Corbyn.Normally, the fact that people are taking to the streets to free themselves of a vicious regime would be cheered to the rafters by the Left.Instead, there is the silence of those who find themselves ­hideously embarrassed.The few who are not ­staring at their shoes claim that Venezuela has been the ­victim of an American plot.That Maduro took, in McDonnell’s words, a “wrong turn” from Chavez’s true socialism.That it was all down to a falling oil price.Yes, Maduro took a wrong turn. But that turn was to follow the path laid out by Chavez.From the Soviet Union to Cuba to Venezuela, there is a long and shabby history of British left-wingers acclaiming a workers’ paradise — only to declare, once its ­failure is clear, that it wasn’t really socialist after all.Never mind the millions of lives ruined — let’s have another go!If he became Prime ­Minister, Corbyn might not succeed in turning Britain into Venezuela. But we’d be Caracas to let him try.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: karren brady influencers dont see kids friends cash
story: Weirdly, for those of us who grew up before the internet took off, that’s an actual job now.And who can blame people for ­saying: “‘Yes please” to money for doing not very much But there is something wrongInstagram users aren’t aware the ­celebrities they follow are being paid thousands of pounds — or even hundreds of thousands — to promote the products they are “recommending”.Advertisers know Instagram — which has a BILLION monthly users posting some million photos a day — is an incredibly powerful way of reaching young people.The more followers a star has, the greater their selling power.Kylie Jenner, who has million ­followers, is paid a whopping £, for every sponsored post.Under the  UK Consumer Protection From Unfair Trading regulations, ­celebrities paid to plug products are supposed to make that clear.But there are no simple guidelines.So while some celebs might say “sponsored” or “#ad” on a post, others are less open about it.That is why the Competition  ­Markets Authority conducted an ­investigation.And this week  British celebrities and “influencers” were found to have failed to follow consumer protection guidelines.They include singers Rita Ora and Ellie Goulding, models Alexa Chung and Rosie Huntington-Whiteley and video blogger Zoella.While all agreed to change their ways, none was taken to court where they might have faced fines or even jail time.“Influencers” might say the clue is in the name. They are paid to inspire you to buy stuff.Most insist they only endorse ­products they actually believe in — and we’d all hope they take their responsibility seriously.But it is easy to see how an offer of, say, £, to endorse something they “sort of” believe in might make it harder to hang on to those principles.Equally,guidelines aren’t strictly enforced, you can understand the temptation to convey the impression that you just happen to really like a particular laxative herbal tea, say, or a moisturiser that gives you a “glow”.It’s a grey area. And you might ask why it matters.But given recent news about the ­negative impact social media can have on the mental health of young people — and young women in particular — regulation of this brave new world affects us all.I need only point to another big story this week.Schoolgirl Molly Russell was  when she took her own le after showing “no obvious signs” of severe mental health issues.Her family later found she had been viewing material on social media linked to anxiety, depression, self-harm and suicide.Her father even went as far as accusing Instagram of “helping to kill her”.Social media makes it so easy to tap into someone’s daily le, their home-decor proclivities and their innermost thoughts.The intimate nature of Instagram lets you feel like these influencers are your friends, and the products they rave about their personal ­recommendations, not the outcome of a business deal.This is a real problem. But the mistake is much harder to makeadverts are clearly labelled as such.Part of the problem is how obsessed with celebrities our young people have become.When I was growing up, my main influenceswere my parents and my friends.Now, young people are influenced by people they will never meet.Some of these people, dare I say it, are talentless nobodies.You might argue you would have to be naive not to realise they are selling you something.Perhaps young people are not as cynical as the likes of me.And that is why regulation is key.IT’S hard to sympathise with Fungi, a “star” of hit telly documentary Benefits Street, who says universal credit is “the worst thing in the world”.Tracked down by this paper, James Clarkeclaimed his monthly payments had been more than halved and the all-in-one benefit was causing “hell” for him and others like him . . . because their booze budget has been cut.Fungi was claiming £ a month to spend on food and sundries. But this was slashed to £ – which doesn’t cover the £ a month he and his partner spend on strong cider.His rent, meanwhile, is paid in full via a separate taxpayer-funded handout.Fungi also says his drinking habit means he can’t work. Sorry, what Here’s another way of looking at it. People who work for eight hours a day don’t have the time to down three litres of cider a day.If Mr Clarke got a job, he might recover some of his self-esteem – and probably save his le in the process.Just to be clear – I BELIEVE in the benefits system.But it was invented to help people get back on their feet, to help those who can’t help themselves because of illness or disability.It should be a short-term measure, not a lestyle choice.In the meantime, the rest of us go to work to pay for this man’s rent and booze.All because he can’t be bothered to sort himself out.No wonder people get angry.In fact, I suspect most readers will have steam coming out of their ears.This man must start taking responsibility for himself.I SUPPOSE it was worth a shot for Diane Abbott to complain that Fiona Bruce was “badly briefed” and that her treatment as a list on Question Time was racist.But she can’t blame Fiona for her own incompetence in answering questions – and not just on Question Time.There are so many car-crash interviews to choose from . . . although the one in which Diane suggested police officers could be paid £ a year springs to mind.WHAT a nasty piece of work Dancing On Ice judge Jason Gardiner seems.We expect the judges to give feedback.And we know it won’t all be good.But his comment to Gemma Collins last week – “We are not going to see big lts from you” – came across as body-shaming.Because his real point is that she is overweight, right It’s shocking, really. I’m surprised ITV allowed it.THE secret behind Elle Macpherson’s phenomenal bod has been revealed.In an interview, she said it all comes down to . . . late breakfasts.Hmmm. No matter when we eat breakfast, most of us will never come close to looking how she does at .Actually, forget breakfast times. What struck me is her diet seems to contain just FIVE ingredients . . . one of which is nut cheese.And the only liquid is water.Elle looks great.But by God, she must be miserable.THE Premier League’s popularity continues to soar, as a study into attendances across Europe proves.And I was immensely proud to see West Ham ranked seventh by attendance in all of Europe last year.We are up there with the Continent’s elite, in a table headed by Barcelona.And that will only get better now the capacity of the London Stadium is up to , – adding to the incredible support we get from what I believe are the league’s best fans.This week, accountancy firm EY published a report on the impact the Premier League has on our economy.It generates £.billion a year in tax for the Exchequer, supporting , jobs and contributing £.billion overall to the country’s GDP.Last season, Premier League players paid more than £billion in taxes.But never mind the money.It’s still the best league in the world.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no delaying halting brexit john mann
story: Across the country people who voted dferent ways in the Brexit referendum are ­becoming bored and irritated by the silly games at Westminster.The truth is that a large majority of MPs are Remainers in their hearts and souls and are struggling to bring themselves to recognise the reality of the situation.It was us MPs who voted to give you, the people, the say on leaving or remaining in the European Union.And you voted, in higher numbers than you have ever bothered voting for any of us. Yet the same MPs who gave you a say are coming up with every excuse for why your views should not be listened to.Of course there are Remainer MPs whose constituencies voted heavily to remain.There are MPs with, I have to say it, courage, who have always argued strongly in a way that they have always known is dferent to their ­voters. These people are ­consistent and have my respect.But there are just as many who are in danger now of sitting on the fence until rigor mortis sets in, coming up with process rather than substance.They are simply hoping that others will do the dirty deed and respect the will of the people.It is also, for every Labour and Conservative MP, the manesto ­promise that we stood on at the last election. We voted for a referendum. We promised to respect the result.We got re-elected promising the same, yet Parliament continues to sit on the roundabout to nowhere.It is time to stop the shenanigans and work across the political ide to bring our country and our people together.At stake is our democracy. And in a democracy the winner prevails.Of course, in future years, people can argue that we have got it wrong and that people are entitled to change their mind. But for democracy to be true and real, we have to deliver the mandate we have been given and leave the EU on March .The referendum ided people and families, with lots of strong and dfering views. But in cherishing our democracy, we now need to come together to deliver a Brexit that respects the people’s vote and helps heal that ide.In le we have to compromise. We all have our own perfect Brexit, me included. And with ten of my colleagues we have forced through a big part of that, guaranteeing in law workers’ rights, health and safety and environmental standards. We will be competing with Europe by being the best, not by being the cheapest.I would love to have been a fly on the wall when Theresa May told union bosses that she was meeting their key demands not just with a promise but with a legal guarantee. But then she knew it was only right, because union members were the bedrock of leave voters across the country.And, I believe, we can get more in the next fortnight. A clear commitment to a once-in-a-generation investment into the Leave-voting areas that have long been starved of our fair shares — those former coal, iron and steel industrial heartlands, the unfashionable places, the areas still manufacturing. I think, as well, that union bosses and industrialists can be brought to act as advisers to the trade negotiations when we have left the EU, bringing their expertise into play to ensure a jobs-first Brexit for Britain.A country, proud and independent, standing on its own two feet, ­confident again in our democracy, bold enough to compete by being the best, British workers making high- quality products and delivering high-quality services.A country that says it will be the best by having better pay, conditions and a healthier environment than anyone  in Europe or worldwide.Is that not something to be confident in voting for, my fellow MPs  Let’s get on with it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cult of brexit remainer fading
story: I will try, but it is hard to see eye to eye with those who regard the .million who voted Out in  as pig- ignorant racists.Or to forgive Chancellor Phil Hammond for twisting Treasury data to undermine the British economy.I will simply wish him well in retirement at the earliest possible moment.Anna Soubry is a bit of a challenge too, but I will ­eventually find something nice to say.As for EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier, even Her ­Eurosceptic Majesty would find little common ground with the man who vowed to punish her United Kingdom for daring to leave.But it will be cult-like Remainers who find it hardest to kiss and make up.Their hatred of Leavers has reached sectarian proportions.Astonishingly a poll found many would ban marriage outside the EU faith.Indeed, my old friendMatthew Parris insists Her Maj was wrong to suggest there is any common ground at all, because it might appear to endorse Theresa May’s dodgy deal.The Times sage has abandoned the Zen-like equilibrium which once made him ­compulsive reading. Along with the likes of megabucks Remainers Tony Blair, Peter Mandelson and PR guru Roland Rudd, he seems to think Brexiters are basically pond le.That theory should be buried forever after this weekend’s passionate plea from leading academic Sir Noel Malcolm for MPs to stop wrecking Brexit.Writing in the devoutly pro-EU Financial Times, this distinguished Fellow of All Souls, Oxford, spells out the essence of the Leave case: “Brexit is about sovereignty — and parliament must respect that.”“If the UK is now on the brink of a constitutional crisis,” he adds, “one major reason is that a signicant number of MPs still oppose any version of Brexit, and seek a second ­referendum solely for the sake of reversing the decision of the last one.”Sir Noel does not believe people voted Out because they were racist.“The most important reason was democracy,” he says.“They wanted to live under laws made by the people they elected. Immigration came second.What they objected to was a supranational government ­making some of their laws and lting all immigration controls on the inhabitants of  other countries.”Another Remainer fiction is that Brexiters are narrow-minded Little Englanders.Yet the Daily Mail found space for a German view that Brussels should stop “insulting Britain” and honour us as champions of peace in Europe.“Such blinkered and sour responses are wrong-headed,” says Alexander von Schoenburg, a senior editor of Germany’s biggest newspaper, Bild.“They ignore the great debt Germany and the whole ­Continent owes our friends across the Channel.“We must always remember that throughout your history, independence and sovereignty have been paramount.“Germany in particular should tread lightly when it comes to dealing with your proud nation. It was Great Britain that first stood up to Hitler in .And it was Britain that opened its doors to thousands of ­Jewish refugees fleeing certain death during the Holocaust.“Put simply, there would be no free Europe without you and the bloody sacrice you made to rescue the Continent.”This remarkable tribute ­follows a recent love letter to the UK from Germany’s next Chancellor calling for a friendly Brexit orce and an end to bitterness.It is now clear hardline Remainers have over-reached themselves. The worm has turned.Talk of a second referendum is dead and voters are on the warpath against MPs plotting to scupper Brexit in tomorrow’s Commons showdown.Brussels is in chaos over the Northern Ireland backstop.Michel Barnier has started muttering about new tech- nology to police post-Brexit ­frontiers — a UK idea initially dismissed as “magical thinking”.EU allies are breaking ranks to demand a decent deal — for their sake as much as ours.It is way past time now for Theresa May to scrap the backstop and tell Brussels exactly what she needs to get her deal through Parliament.“There is absolutely no truth in speculation that ­passengers are being advised not to book,” stormed Brittany Ferries as it announced plans to INCREASE services.Meanwhile, mischief-making aviation giant Airbus admits it was asked by Downing Street to warn – incredibly – that it would shut up shopBritain left without a deal.Project Fear is shameless.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: molly russell social media blame

title: this morning nta ally ross tv opinion
story: Six days a week now, This Morning hammers home the message its viewers are the most helpless, mollycoddled invertebrates on the planet.A form of le so useless that last November Dr Chris Steele, the show’s resident quack, genuinely felt the need to give us all bottom-wiping advice.“It’s a front-to-back action for women,” more of a hit-and-hope exercise for men.Infor this constant nannying, we pick up a phone once a year and gurgle: “You’re absolutely right. We are useless. Have a trophy.”And it’s a depressing cycle that will continue for as long as there are National Television Awards, live from The O.A ceremony where the categories may chop and change every year, but the stupidity remains ritualised.As well as getting all the usual winners though, viewers also had to endure a technical nightmare on Tuesday, where things went wrong — from the shambolic opening scenes right through to the unedited version of the closing credits: “With thanks to — Television Centre White City or just Television Centretoo long.”It’s always a case of fine margins, of course, at the NTAs, and the evening might have strayed into so-bad-it’s-good territorythe cameras had just focused on one of the Love Island gang when host Dermot O’Leary said: “Danny DeVito will be in Dumbo next year.”They didn’t, though. So a night bedevilled by sound issues, rotten acceptance speeches and foul Danny Dyer language was crowned by Special Recognition winner David Dimbleby eulogising the BBC and ordering us to be nicer to politicians, in a speech that could hardly be descri- bed as “mood capturing”.It’s the awards themselves though, that I know get viewers’ goats the most, starting, painful as it is to admit, with the fact perennial winners This Morning absolutely robbed Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain operation in the Daytime category.Given that Jack Whitehall’s Travels With My Father managed to scrape on to the Comedy shortlist, there’s also an argument that says Chunk, Charlotte Hawkins, Richard Arnold and Susanna Reid — who was styled quite magnicently on the night as Waitrose’s answer to Vicky Pattison — should have made that final five as well.Because almost no show made me laugh as loud or as regularly as Good Morning Britain did in .A glaring omission too in the TV Judge section — always won by David Walliams — which included X Factor’s Robbie Williams on the shortlist, but not Craig Revel Horwood, who didn’t take a two-week sabbatical in the middle of Strictly, cost the BBC £million or throw in his other half as part of the deal.The award that made a nonsense of the whole occasion though was Ant  Dec winning Best Presenters for the th time in a row, despite the presence of Bradley Walsh and Graham Norton on the shortlist, and the fact Ant spent far more weeks in rehab than he did in a TV studio.The mutual affection is touching in one way, of course, but it ultimately does neither them nor the NTAs any good at all and has robbed both of a glorious moment of redemption when they win the  award.Before that foregone conclusion takes place, please stay tuned to This Morning and sit tight until mid-March, when Dr Chris will be along with part II of his bottom-wiping masterclass: Flushing, FLU-SHING.Practially the only programme I watched at the weekend that wasn’t punctuated by uncontrollable sobbing fits from the participants was BBC’s landmark Holocaust documentary The Last Survivors.Men and women who are all in their late eighties and nineties now and understand that time is precious.When you’re a living part of history you also know facts are far more precious than tears.So in the words of the remarkable Anita Lasker-Wallfisch, who avoided the Auschwitz gas chamber purely because she could play the cello: “I won’t give people the pleasure of seeing my emotions.”The very least we owe all of them is an audience. The Last Survivors is available on the BBC iPlayer and will probably be the most unforgettable  minutes of television you’ll watch all year.At approximately : hours, Sunday, Gemma Collins stumbled over while Dancing On Ice.The tectonic plates groaned a little on impact, the front row scattered like ten pins and there was a surge on the national grid as several million viewers went “click, rewind, play,” then “click, rewind, play,” again.In fact, by the time I’d stopped rewinding and playing, Gemma had “bounced back,”and Piers Morgan, no doubt angling for a Le Stories interview, had claimed it was “the gutsiest thing I’ve seen on a talent show” – probably since the days Piers himself was wedged in behind the judges’ desk on Britain’s Got Talent.It was an undeniably great television moment, though.A proper face plant, with a full Klinsmann snow plough to finish.The downside, obviously, is that it’s guaranteed she’ll be back next week, when Melody, Wes, James and the others will be performing to a Fairytale theme and Gemma will be clearing the B Fettercairn to Banchory road,ITV want to find a proper use for her.Click, rewind, play.Things remain cheerful as hell on EastEnders.Alfie Moon’s car has been discovered near some clfs and a policeman has the job of breaking the most awful news imaginable to Kat and the Slaters.“Considering the location and the evidence at hand, we would suggest you prepare yourself for the worst.”Big Mo: “You understand what they’re saying ”Yes, bloody Redwater’s getting a second series. Stay strong, viewers.Celebrity Coach Trip, Roxanne Pallett: “I knew as soon as Jedward got on the coach it was going to be fun.”The One Show, Matt Baker: “If you haven’t seen The Greatest Dancer yet, watch it on the iPlayer. It’s well worth it.”And Icons, Kathleen Turner: “Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and smash social barriers.”No, Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and make people laugh.Tell the BBC to try it some time.Good Morning Britain, Piers Morgan: “Every cloud. We lost the NTA, but I got a kiss off Gemma Collins.” Yeah, every cloud’s got a gigantic p***-storm.No one from Peaky Blinders bothering to turn up to the NTAs to thank: “The best fans a show could hope for.”Celebrity Coach Trip contestants Jedward ­providing the finest argument yet for theof a hard Irish border.Sheridan Smith’s accent doing the London to Doncaster trip in . seconds flat, on that Cleaning Up tosh.The Greatest Dancer’s pre-performance sob stories straying horribly close to moral blackmail territory.And E fly-on-the-wall moron Vogue Williams asking: “Is Gandhi the Dalai Lama ” in total ­ignorance of this remarkable man’s wisdom, serenity and even his landmark campaign for Dolce  Gabbana’s Light Blue fragrance . . .Martin Keown: “It should be a great spectacle, so sit back, hide behind the sofa and enjoy it.”Phil Thompson: “You never know what’s going to happen and that’s exactly what happened.”And Paul Merson: “If he was at Arsenal doing this, he wouldn’t be doing it.”.This week’s winner is the bellowing great Orca herself, Gemma Collins, and Sugar, from Total Drama Island.Sent in by Rich, of Lincolnshire. Picture research: Alfie Snelling.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “At the  Olympics, what birds were first released as a symbol of peace ” Georgina: “Eagle.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “What is the name of the monument in Trafalgar Square built in ­honour of Admiral Horatio Nelson ”Gemma: “Pass.”Ben Shephard: “Which British comedian ­presented the television programme Backchat with his father Michael ”Linda: “Jasper Carrott.”And Ben Shephard: “The Tartan Army is the nickname for fans of which national football team ” Najam: “Newcastle United.”Najam. A word . . .ITV’s The Paras: Men Of War, evenit needed three more episodes and better editing.BBC’s The Last Survivors. Tom Jones singing Cry To Me, with the talented Bethzienna Williams, on The Voice.The sudden, joyful NTA realisation the old bald bloke with the white beard in row A was Tim Lovejoy.And Celebrity Coach Trip guide Brendan Sheerin telling Jedward, Charlotte Crosby, Roxanne Pallett et al: “Today, you’re all going to a donkey sanctuary.” Well it’s about time.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nick timothy brady brexit vote
story: With the deadlock among MPs still not broken, nobody knows for sure what will happen.Theresa May says Brexit must go ahead on time. But she also says Britain will not leave the EU without a deal.And her deal — the only one on the table at this late stage — was defeated in the House of Commons by a record majority just two weeks ago.Tonight’s Brexit votes are not quite the final shoot-out between the dferent factions in Parliament. The Government has promised that MPs will vote soon on a new plan.Remainers and soft Brexit supporters in government are pushing to hold that vote as soon as possible.And MPs — backed by a Speaker who will rewrite any Commons rules to soften or stop Brexit — will force more votes on what happens next.Nevertheless, tonight’s votes do matter.One proposal comes from Yvette Cooper, a Labour MP.Her Yorkshire constituents voted to leave the EU by more than two to one and, during the election, she promised them she would “not vote to block Brexit.”Yet that is what her plan does:     MPs vote for her   amendment, they will be able to stop Brexit happening this year.Cooper has the support of several rebel Tories, soJeremy Corbyn whips his MPs to vote for it, she stands a good chance of getting her way.Caroline Spelman and Jack Dromey, Conservative and Labour, have an amendment that calls on the Government to avoid a no-deal Brexit.Dominic Grieve wants MPs to control the Commons timetable, allowing Parliament to vote on dferent ways of watering Brexit down.Labour want to present MPs with options that include, predictably, a second referendum.Despite drafting a manesto saying “Labour accepts the referendum result”, the Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer says in a second referendum he would campaign to overturn the result of the first.It is possible that none of these amendments might pass.Remainers and soft Brexiteers are ided about what should happen.Some want to delay Brexit, some want to tie us to European rules and regulations, and others want another referendum to stop it altogether.Evenno proposal wins a Commons majority, the votes cast by MPs will probably demonstrate that there is a majority to water down Brexit one way or another.For Brexit supporters, this is very dangerous indeed.Some believe they simply need to run down the clock and, in  days, we can leave without a deal.For Leavers who want a negotiated departure, this feels like a serious risk.But Leavers who favour no deal need to ask themselves, can they really be so sure they will get what they want With several Cabinet ministers, many more junior ministers and a Commons majority against no deal, it seems increasingly likely that MPs will ultimately find a way of stopping no deal.When they do, Brexit will only get softer and softer.This is why the amendment proposed by Graham Brady, a senior Conservative, is so important.His idea is to approve the Prime Minister’s original Brexit deal, but with the “backstop” removed.The backstop is hated by unionists, because to prevent barriers to trade between Ireland and Northern Ireland, it creates new barriers to trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.And it is hated by Leavers, because it ties the UK to the EU’s customs union, and Northern Ireland to EU single market rules.Brady wants MPs to vote simply for “alternative arrangements” to the backstop.By avoiding a specic proposal, he hopes the amendment can win a Commons majority and, in doing so, demonstrate to Brussels that the deal they struck with Theresa May can be ratied — but only without the backstop.Critics, largely Remainers, say this is impossible.But in the past week or so, Angela Merkel has questioned whether the backstop is such a good idea after all.The Polish foreign minister has suggested it should expire after five years. And the European Commission effectively conceded that in the event of no deal, they would use policy and technology to prevent a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.In other words, they proposed solutions they once dismissed as “unicorns” and “magical thinking” when they were suggested by the British — and which could render the backstop unnecessary.But this is not all. Some European officials have floated, in private, a more inventive solution: that the UK and Ireland should form a British Isles customs zone, with Britain compensating Ireland for any new friction in their trade with Europe.So it is clear: whatever Remainers claim, alternatives to the backstop are technically and politically feasible.Recognising this, the Brady amendment would give the Government one last chance to negotiate something better.Yet Tory Brexiteers say they might not vote for it. They fear the ambiguity of “alternative arrangements” could allow ministers to negotiate an even worse deal, perhaps tying the whole of the UK to the EU’s customs union and single market rules for good.They do not trust May, her advisers, or most of her Cabinet and demand a specic time limit on the backstop.Butthey vote down the Brady amendment, they will not get what they want, and are more likely to get what they fear.As the clock ticks on and bottoms get even squeakier, MPs will coalesce around a plan to stop a no-deal Brexit.The EU will have no reason to compromise, and Parliament will soften our departure by aligning us with more and more European laws.If Leavers vote against Brady, they will be shooting themselves not in one foot, and not even in both feet, but in the head.As the Commons debates the proposals today, Leavers need to start compromising with reality. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: penny mordaunt foreign aid target
story: She delivered a presentation to Cabinet colleagues on a detailed plan to tweak rules that would slash the amount taxpayers contribute to the bloated £ billion a year budget.Ms Mordaunt told weekly meeting - chaired by the Prime Minister - that the Government could then use the savings to boost NHS spending and “other domestic priorities”.Cabinet ministers also backed moves to use the foreign aid budget to support Britain’s Armed Forces and humanitarian missions.The strict rules by the OECD’s Development Assistance Committeemean millions of pounds of aid spending do not count towards the . per cent of national income target.Hundreds of millions of our aid spending is spent through private firms - such as the CDC Group.These contractors make profits, which are then invested back into foreign aid projects, but the rules bar these profits from being counted towards the . per cent target.Ms Mordaunt said changing the rules to allow this reinvested profit to count towards the target would free up millions of pounds for other departments by shaving the bloated aid budget.She said this would also allow her Department for International Developmentto “move from being a spending department to a fundraising department”.Ms Mordaunt told Cabinet that the . per cent “in its current form is unsustainable” but changing rules would help the foreign aid obligations become “less reliant” on the public purse.She launched a new consultation with charities, financial services, investors and the public about how to allocate more private money towards the foreign aid target.Ms Mordaunt said the review will also look into how money invested in saving and pension funds could deliver more s for UK investors.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nick clegg job fix facebook molly russell
story: The former Deputy Prime Minister, last seen being booted out by the voters of Sheffield Hallam, has re-emerged as Facebook’s Mr Fixit — the man tasked by its CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, with rescuing the reputation of the embattled internet firm.Having claimed that “I actually find the messianic Calornian new-worldy-touchy-feely culture of Facebook a little grating”, Sir Nick has duly installed himself in a £million mansion near San Francisco, ready to offer his expertise.Some people have been puzzled about why the world’s most powerful social media company, owner of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp, would recruit a man whose main brush with online fame was an autotuned video of him apologising for betraying the public over tuition fees.In fact, Clegg and Zuckerberg are a match made in heaven. Both are powered by an inexorable sense of self-righteousness. And both have an awful lot of experience of saying sorry.The most recent example came when Sir Nick appeared on the BBC in the wake of the furore over the death of -year-old Molly Russell.It turned out, after she was found dead in her bedroom in December , that she had been viewing material online relating to depression, self-harm and suicide — material which was shockingly easy to find.As her father Ian Russell put it bluntly: “Instagram helped kill my daughter.”Sir Nick, to his credit, said all the right things about how the firm was determined to do more. But he also made the striking claim that it is sometimes better for Facebook and Instagram to keep suicide images online, because it helps other vulnerable young people get support.This after The Sun, on Saturday, found and flagged up multiple images appearing to normalise and even romanticise suicide, all within a few clicks. Many remained published for days, and a Facebook spokesman claimed they could be beneficial to users battling mental health issues.Sir Nick says the firm is following the advice from leading experts and charities. And it may well be doing the right thing. But this is the latest example of Facebook — and other social media giants in general — only acting to tackle a problem once it becomes impossible not to.Over the past decade, social media has come to dominate our lives. The latest research from Ofcom shows internet use rocketing among children and teenagers, with friendships and social lives increasingly run through screens and phones.And it is now clear that this great move online has been accompanied, for our children, by a staggering increase in mental health problems.The situation is particularly alarming when it comes to young women. The latest NHS data found that one in four of those aged  to  report having a mental health disorder — twice the rate among boys.In  alone, one in five US girls aged between  and  suffered a major depressive episode — one in five! Suicide rates for teenage girls, according to academic Jonathan Haidt, have risen by  per cent in the US and  per cent in the UK in a decade.This isn’t just about what happens on the internet. Those having problems online often tend to be experiencing problems offline too, such as bullying, harassment or broken families.More broadly, Haidt believes the “snowflake” phenomenon reflects that “helicopter parenting” leaves children less prepared to cope with shocks and dficulty. But the internet, and social media, are very clearly intensying those problems. And the big tech firms are still playing catch-up.The traditional argument from Silicon Valley is that it’s not their job to regulate human behaviour. They add that eventhey wanted to, there is simply too much out there.They are doing their best to crack down on inappropriate content, but it’s like trying to stem the tide. Behind the scenes — they insist — thousands of people are working day and night to detect and delete messages promoting terrorism, hatred, Holocaust denial and self-harm.But this argument just doesn’t wash. It’s very clear that, in the interests of their bottom lines, many of the big social media firms have long failed to put enough resources into detecting damaging content.Researchers have shown, for example, how following the recommended links from reputable YouTube content can lead to a carnival of horrors. News reports that segue into crackpot conspiracy theories and videos for toddlers that give way to horrendous scenes of a bloodied Minnie Mouse trapped in an escalator.Every day brings new horror stories, such as rival fans of royals Kate and Meghan using the Kensington Palace Instagram to send death threats to each other. Increasingly, online hate is triggering real-le violence. The slaughter of the Rohingya Muslims in Burma was, The New York Times said, “a genocide incited on Facebook”.Part of the reason that Zuckerberg has hired Clegg is to put his house in order. Clegg has talked the right talk about changing Facebook’s culture, and in particular doing more to tackle self-harm.He even says they might start paying more tax. ButZuckerberg’s answer to “how to fix the internet” is “hire Nick Clegg”, we have still got an awfully long way to go.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle national theatre beams arrives visit patron
story: Wearing towering £ Aquazzura heels, the Duchess of Sussex could barely contain her delight as she arrived for her “debut performance” as royal patron – having taken over from the Queen.Its believed the Duchess - title: mum girl born half arm told cover up
story: Gracie Morgans mum moved the two-year-old after hearing the little boy say he was frightened by her small left arm.But the boys mother then came over - and said Gracies arm shouldnt be so obvious because it was scaring other children.Gracie had been wearing a short sleeved dress at the soft play centre in Llanelli, West Wales.Mum-of-four Sarah said: Gracie was happily playing when a little boy started to take an interest in her small arm.This happens a lot and Im not very comfortable with people staring but children are curious and thats OK.But then the little boy started to say he was scared so I took Gracie and moved her to play with her brothers in a dferent part of the playground.Thats when the boys mother came over. She said I shouldnt make Gracies arm so obvious because it was scaring the children.I was so angry I just gathered up the kids and left. I didnt trust myself to respond.Nurse Sarah, , said it isnt the first time she has had cruel comments made about Gracie in public.She said: Ive started to dread going to play groups and soft play because of the negative attention.One time an older boy was circling Gracie and pointing and laughing while his parents just looked on.People dont know what to say. I dont knowthey feel awkward but its cruel to allow that bullying and its the parents I blame not the kids.Gracie, of Llwynhendy, near Llanelli, lives with mum Sarah, dad Gareth Morgan,  and her brothers Cai, nine, Codi, five, and Alfie, three.Sarah added: At the moment Grace is young and doesnt understand. Nothing stops her and I want her to always be that way.Shell hold a crisp packet between her feet and use her right hand to eat. title: couple engaged greggs postman proposes sausage roll
story: True romantic Nick Sawyer, , proposed to partner of two years Carolyn Bennett in a branch of the bakery in Wolverhampton on Sunday.Carolyn, , had lived opposite Nick for a decade but it was only after eight years that he finally plucked up the courage to ask her out.Nick, , said he had considered waiting for a more appropriate moment to hand over the diamond ring, which he had bought just minutes before from a jeweller next door, but decided the time was right.The dad-of-two and grandad-of-three said: I had just been in the jeweller next door, and afterwards we went into Greggs and had a cup of tea and a sausage roll.We had talked about marriage, so it was just a case of when the proposal was going to happen.I knew Carolyn didn’t want a big party, so while we were in Greggs I pulled out the ring and said ‘shall I put it on now ’I didn’t actually get down on one knee, but she was still very happy.Teaching assistant Carolyn added: Weve been going to Greggs a lot recently – its friendly and reasonably priced.We had discussed getting married, but I wasn’t expecting it quite then.Nick got the ring out while we were sat in Greggs and asked meI wanted to wait, but I said I wanted to have it now!Its about the two of us, we just wanted to do it for us and so that was how we did it.It made us realise you’ve just got to go for it. It was always the plan it was just getting round to it.It was a lovely proposal – it was emotional.Carolyn said that she and her hubby-to-be are looking forward to their future – but haven’t set a date for their nuptials yet.She said: Nick is a calm and kind man, but Im biased obviously.Were looking forward to our le together and to be with each other.

title: moment dog bit toddler child gate
story: Isabelle Binns, aged one, from Lincolnshire was pulled with such force as she stroked the golden retriever that the gate came off its hinges.The terrying incident happened while the youngster was staying at her grandmother Julie Booth’s home in Woods Terrace in Gainsborough, Lincolnshire, on Friday, January .Isabelle placed her hand near a safety gate only for the dog to grab her arm with its teeth.The gate fell on the dog and Julie was quickly on hand to rescue the baby, who was left with five deep puncture wounds to her arm following the attack from fostered pooch, which was staying at the home while it waited to be sheltered.The distressing video was caught on camera by the home CCTV and has been shared to Lincolnshire Live by Isabelle’s father, Michael Binns.“My partner and I went out on Thursday night so we left our daughter with her grandma,” the -year-old said.“My partner [Cha] got the call from her mum as I was back at work as a LIVES first aid responder.The dog dragged her through the safety gate and bit into her arm. She was used as a the battering ram for the safety gate.“My daughter was screaming the house down, I can imagine it was quite frightening for a one-year-old.”After learning what had happened, the worried parents were keen to make sure their child was ok.He added: My partner went round said her arm was punctured and bleeding. I had to leave quickly and cleaned it up before the ambulance got there.”The little girl was taken to hospital and has since been given the all clear.The dog has since been put down by the company who arranged the fostering, according to Mr Binns.He said: “It was a golden retriever so it was quite a surprise as they are usually quite nice.Luckily enough she doesn’t seem traumatised. Her auntie came round with a poodle the next day and Isabelle went straight up to it and stroked it. I don’t knowit will be dferentit is a golden retriever.”Mr Binns has been left unhappy after claiming the police officer who attended said that the dog didn’t need to be put down, but just left with owners away from families - a comment Mr Binns says is absolutely shocking.Lincolnshire Police have confirmed officers have attended the incident but have yet to comment on the claims made about the police officer.A spokesperson for EMAS confirmed paramedics were sent to the scene.“We received a call at .am on January  to a medical emergency in a private address in Gainsborough.We sent a crewed ambulance and one patient was taken to Scunthorpe General Hospital.”

story: The stunning country home with spectacular views of the Devon countryside was created by an architect and his we and has been described as London docklands apartment meets rural barn.Mike and Ruth Derry snapped up the derelict building two years ago and converted it into two , sq-ft homes, one for themselves and the other up for grabs for potential buyers.The property, called Southside, has exposed timbers, bespoke fittings and plenty of renewable energy features, including solar , an air source heat pump and a double-sided log burner.The house is highly insulated and has electrically-controlled roof windows, as well as water supplied from a newly-drilled borehole.At their property, Northside, the Derrys also plan to become more self-sufficient by keeping livestock and growing a vegetable garden and planting fruit trees.Southside has , sq-ft of accommodation with an entrance hall and an open plan living space that works as a kitchen, dining room and living room.The family will have a utility room, pantry, games and TV room as well as four spacious bedrooms.Outside it has landscaped gardens of about half an acre and then beyond it has stunning views of the surrounding countryside with rolling hills, fields and woodland as far as the eye can see.Mrs Derry, , who is a tennis coach and drama teacher, said: We decided we wanted to build something from scratch and spent a summer walking everywhere trying to find a cow shed.We found this steel-framed shed with epic views. story: Emily Javier, , chopped off two of Alex Lovells fingers during the assault and later admitted that her purpose was to kill him.On Wednesday she pleaded guilty to to attempted first-degree domestic violence murder.Javier, who was with Lovell, , for two years, told police how she went to a local mall and purchased a samurai sword after finding Tinder on his phone earlier this year.She claimed to have not only found the app but also strands of red hair in their shower.Javier also admitted she attacked her ex because he played video games and ignored her.According to an affidavit, she told police: I was trying to kill him for cheating. title: who lord digby jones what said about brexit
