title: eu theresa may brexit jump out window ireland
story: Simon Coveney snfed that the British government was being unreasonable for trying to change the hated Northern Ireland backstop - even though MPs have shown they simply wont agree to it.It comes as Brussels bosses piled in to tell the PM that her Brexit deal was NOT up for renegotiation - just seconds after MPs in the Commons told her she needed to change it.May was boosted after winning support for a new deal that means she will have to scrap the controversial backdrop.But Mr Coveney, who is the countrys foreign affairs minister, insisted today that it was extraordinary she was now going back to tear up her deal - and urged her to go for a soft Brexit instead.In an odd rant he claimed that she shouldnt be threatening to leave no deal.Thats like saying, in a negotiation, either you give me what I want or Im jumping out of the window, he told RTE Radio.And said later on that there were no such alternative arrangements to replace the backstop that existed.We need a backstop or insurance mechanism based on legal certainty, and not just wishful thinking.We are quite simply running out of road.The Irish Taoiseach told Theresa May in a call today that the position of the Irish remains unchanged.A spokesperson said the latest developments had reinforced the need for a backstop is legally robust and workable.The PM told him that further consultations are taking place in London on the backstop.But DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds accused the Irish Government of highly reckless talk over the potential of a no-deal Brexit to cause trouble at the border, before talking of how a hole had been blown through the backstop.Within seconds of the result last night, EU chiefs repeated their claim that it will be impossible to renegotiate the withdrawal agreement.A coordinated statement from the European Council read: “Withdrawal agreement is and remains best and only way to ensure an orderly withdrawal of the UK from the EU.The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation.The remarks were echoed by French President Emmanuel Macron, who insisted the Brexit deal was “not renegotiable”.And EU Council Boss Donald Tusk called on the UK to “clary its intentions with respect to its next steps as soon as possible”.Today Michel Barnier said Mrs May was distancing herself from the deal shes already signed up to.Top Eurocrat Jean Claude Juncker doubled down too - stating: The withdrawal agreement will not be negotiated.He said this afternoon that the Commons vote last night doesnt change anything and the deal remains the best and only deal possible.Yesterdays vote has further increased the risk of a disorderly exit of the UK, he insisted, but said the bloc would remain calm, united and determined.But in a testy exchange, Mr Raab, who quit over Mrs May’s Brexit deal last year,  told MPs on the Northern Ireland committee this morning that the reports were “factually incorrect.”He insisted that he had a “constructive”  meeting with Simon Coveney to discuss plans to make the Irish border work after Brexit.And that he kept details of the dinner confidential at his request.But later on details of the dinner emerged in the papers, and the Irish Taoiseach commented on them.“It was simply not what I discussed or what I proposed, Mr Raab said.Elsewhere he also accused the Irish government of taking a “trenchant line” on the backstop.And the strong positions taken by the Government mean it will be hard to find a “ladder to climb down”.Mr Raab  insisted that a way forward for the Irish border based on checks away from the frontiersneeded and “good will” from both sides.He pointed out that Michel Barnier himself was looking at ways to protect the integrity of the single market in the event that Britain left without a deal in March.“If it can be done in  months, it must be possible to be done in two years,” he argued.Yesterday, in a private phone call before the votes took place, he told Mrs May the same thing - the EU wouldnt be budging.And German MEP Manfred Weber, a close ally of Angela Merkel, claimed Gibraltar would be at riskBrexit talks restarted.He said: If there is now a unilateral attempt to reopen the agreement, the consequence will be that not just the backstop has to be renegotiated then the Gibraltar question, the question of how much money Britain has to pay for exiting, the question of citizens rights will have to be renegotiated.If we reopen, then everything will be reopened. And to be honest, I dont see much sense in that.Emmanuel Macron insisted the current deal is the best possible and said it was not renegotiable.EU bosses have repeatedly said the -page withdrawal agreement thrashed out in November cant be changed.They claim any tweaks must be confined to the attached political declaration, which is not legally binding.Today Mrs May told the Commons she would seek a signicant and legally binding change to the withdrawal agreement.The PM added: Negotiating such a change will not be easy - it will involve re-opening the withdrawal agreement, a move for which I know there is limited appetite among our European partners.But I believe that with a mandate from this house, I can secure such a change in advance of our departure from the EU.British officials believe the EU will agree to new talks to avoid a No Deal outcome which would harm the continent.

title: theresa may jeremy corbyn denies soft brexit
story: The Labour leader finally met the PM to discuss breaking the Brexit impasse this afternoon and his spokesman claimed they discussed keeping Britain locked into a customs union with Europe.But the united front has quickly disintegrated, with a No source rejecting Labours claims and saying May did no more than ask questions.Furthermore, Corbyn went straight onto Sky News to accuse Mrs May of running down the clock on Brexit.Speaking this evening, Mr Corbyn said: The whole process looks like its running down the clock by saying, well, its either the problems and the dficulties of No Deal or support a deal thats already been rejected by the House of Commons.Im suspicious that there is a programme of running down the clock here.But Brexiteers will be fuming at the suggestion that the PM could water down Brexit and keep us tied to the EU forever.Earlier today the PM attacked him for having no clue about what he really wants for our EU exit and failing to listen to her plan to push the bloc for more concessions on the backstop.The Labour boss is scheduled for talks with the Prime Minister later after repeatedly snubbing her offer of working together for the sake of the country.During PMQs this afternoon she said: Time and time again hes told me to listen to the views of this House.But he has no plan for Brexit, no good plan for our economy, and no plan for our country!The PM told him shes openly considering proposals to put a time-limit on the backstop, a way to exit the backstop, and Jacob Rees-Mogg and Nicky Morgans so-called Plan C.Hes the one who is risking no deal - Im working to ensure we get a deal. He has opposed every move by this government to get a deal, she added.Meanwhile, the Labour boss is under pressure to sack Labour rebels from his top team who humiliated him in last nights vote.Last night eight MPs from the Labour frontbench opted to abstain on the crunch vote on Yvette Coopers No Deal plan.The  MPs who did not vote on the plot - most of whom are from Leave supporting towns and fear reprisals from their voters - could have almost swung the vote the other way.Labour threw their weight behind Ms Coopers plan to delay Brexitno deal had been reached by the end of the next month, which would have paved the way for a second referendum or stopping Brexit altogether.The group of abstainers included shadow early years minister Tracy Brabin, shadow justice minister Gloria De Piero, and shadow minister for local government, Jim McMahon.But they are likely to keep their jobs so that Labour can continue their carefully balanced position trying to appease both Leavers and Remainers.Mr Corbyn said: Im very disappointed in those that chose to vote with the Conservatives last night on those issues.But askedher would sack them, he said only: We will be having discussions with them.The party has been on the fence on Brexit ever since the referendum to try and appeal to both sides of the debate.AGAINST:Ian AustinKevin BarronRonnie CampbellRosie CooperJim FitzpatrickCaroline FlintRoger GodsfStephen HepburnKate HoeyJohn MannDennis SkinnerLaura SmithGareth SnellGraham Stringer ABSTAINED:Tracy BrabinJudith CumminsGloria De PieroYvonne FogueMike KaneEmma Lewell-BuckJim McMahonMelanie OnnRuth SmeethJohn SpellarStephen TwiggThey dont want to lose support in their Northern towns and cities - which voted Leave - but many of their supporters also backed Remain in the South.Last night the leaders office refused to sayany of the group would be sacked for failing to vote with the rest of the party.Several of Mr Corbyns backbench MPs from Leave areas voted against the amendment too in an attempt to try and stay on the good side of their voters.Meanwhile, the Labour boss is set to meet Theresa May later today to discuss Brexit - after he finally accepted her offer for talks.Hes repeatedly said he wont see her until she insists we wont leave the EU without a deal.In another dramatic night in Westminster yesterday:Last night Mr Corbyn said he looked forward to discussing his concerns with her.Labours shadow trade secretary Barry Gardiner this morning insisted he hadnt backtracked, but that MPs last night had told them with a non-binding vote that they would never back No Deal.He told the BBC: Jeremy always said that all she needed to do at this stage, she didnt need to actually physically remove it, she didnt need to pass legislation, she just needed to accept that that was the will of the House and that would be what happened.

title: brexit backstop news latest theresa may brussels
story: Top Eurocrats Jean-Claude Juncker and Michel Barnier both blasted the PM in public and mocked her efforts to salvage the deal.The PM has vowed to fix the Irish backstop after uniting her party in last nights crunch Commons vote.But Eurocrats have insisted the existing deal cant be rewritten - setting up a huge bust-up between Britain and the EU.Mr Barnier, Brussels Brexit envoy, told the European Parliament: The backstop is part and parcel of the withdrawal agreement and this agreement will not be renegotiated.European Commission president Mr Juncker added: The withdrawal agreement remains the best and only deal possible. The debate and votes in the House of Commons yesterday do not change that.This is not a game. Irelands border is Europes border and is our unions priority.This evening Mrs May will confront chief Eurocrat Donald Tusk in a crunch phone call.After winning support for a plan to ditch the backstop proposal - designed to keep the Irish border open - the PM promised MPs shed play hardball with Brussels.Mrs May told the Commons today she wont back down on her red lines of taking Britain out of the EU customs union and ending open-doors migration.The PM said: The plan that was set out last night shows that we can get a substantial and sustainable majority in this house.And she ridiculed Remainer efforts to rule out No Deal without saying what should happen instead - saying: Last night the house did vote to reject No Deal but that cannot be the end of the story. You cant just vote to reject No Deal, you have to vote for a deal.Now MPs have signalled they want “alternative arrangements” to the hated Northern Ireland backstop, then she can tell the EU thatthey make the change, Parliament is almost certain to sign it off in the coming weeks.Mrs May will speak to EU leaders today and the rest of the week - and could dash to Brussels for emergency talks too to thrash out a compromise.If they manage to get a change, she will then give MPs another vote on her deal within weeks.If not, the PM will probably tell her MPs it’s her deal or nothing, having fought with the EU as much as possible but to no avail.MPs who fear crashing out could then turn around at the last minute and back the deal.But the EU claims its not possible to impose legally binding changes on the existing deal.In a furious rant, Irish deputy PM Simon Coveney compared Mrs May to someone saying, Give me what I want or Ill jump out of the window.But Polands prime minister Mateusz Morawiecki gave Mrs May a glimmer of hope, saying: Acting together, with all EU member states, we should do our best to avoid hard Brexit.And the European shipping industry body demanded movement from the EU and warned that without an agreement there will only be losers at all sides.A Downing Street source admitted there would be a clash with the EU but insisted there would be space for compromise later this week.The source said: We always knew the next  hours would be a firefight and they’ll say ‘no, no no’.We’ll see what happens after that. It’s a positive day but only the start of what will be an incredibly challenging process.”Brexiteers warned Brussels thatthey dont agree to fresh talks on the deal, they risk Britain crashing out of the EU without a deal on March .Jacob Rees-Mogg told talkRADIO: If they think that the withdrawal agreement is not negotiable, then we must leave without an agreement.Ex-minister Greg Hands added: Brussels is risking a hard Brexit.And Dominic Raab said: The balls now in the EUs court - theyve got to decide.Speaking in the Commons, Mark Harper warned fellow Brexit backers to give the Prime Minister space to get concessions out of the EU.He told MPs: Theyre not going to crumble tomorrow - were going to have to hold our nerve.The backstop is hated by Brexiteers because they fear it will leave Britain trapped in the customs union permanently.They want to see it replaced by technical measures which can carry out automatic checks on goods travelling between Northern Ireland and Republic.Last night the anti-backstop amendment tabled by senior Tory Sir Graham Brady passed through the Commons by  votes.At the same time MPs voted against a motion from Yvette Cooper which would have taken No Deal off the table.But the PM has promised them another vote on the way forward on Valentines Day where Remainers could restart their anti-Brexit campaign.

title: brexit second referendum peoples vote
story: Remainers are worried that a second referendum could be off the table in the wake of last nights Commons showdown.Theyre now gearing up for another push next month - but fear that could be the final chance to delay Brexit and secure a so-called peoples vote.Remain campaigners last night piled in behind a wrecking amendment tabled by Labours Yvette Cooper.But the motion, which would have seen Brexit pushed backBritain is heading for No Deal, was defeated by  votes.Pro-EU Tory Anna Soubry lamented: We’ve come closer to crashing out.The odds of a second referendum have slipped to   in the wake of the vote, from   at the beginning of this week, according to Ladbrokes.The Remainers are now pinning their hopes on a Valentines Day debate when the PM will give MPs another chance to have their say on the way forward.A senior source from one of the anti-Brexit campaigns told The Sun: It was a bad night - its worrying that we didnt have the numbers to extend Article .I think February  is the last chance saloon now.Brexit backers also claimed the result of last nights votes showed a rerun of the  vote isnt going to happen.Ex-minister Greg Hands said today: Support for a second referendum is so low amongst MPs that nobody even bothered to put it to the vote.Other Remainers insisted the campaign isnt dead and vowed to secure a victory next month.A Lib Dem source said: A handful of Labour MPs got the Tories out of a tight spot.But it was a pyrrhic victory - were just going to end up back at square one after the PMs macabre tour of Europe. Well try again on February .And former Cabinet minister Peter Hain, a backer of the Peoples Vote campaign, added: In two weeks the Prime Minister willto Parliament, and MPs should then reject a No Deal Brexit and instead support a people’s vote.After her victory last night, Theresa May is planning to head to Brussels to demand changes to the withdrawal agreement.

title: theresa may has 58 days to make brexit happen heres all the ways it could go
story: But the PM still has to cross several more bridges before finally getting the deal over the line - starting with a trip to Brussels." data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   DD-COMPOSITE-BREXIT-FLOW-CHART.jpg stripallw" src"data:image svg+xml,%Csvg xmlnshttp:www.w.org  svg viewBox  . %E%C svg%E"  " data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   DD-COMPOSITE-BREXIT-FLOW-CHART-.jpg stripallw" src"data:image svg+xml,%Csvg xmlnshttp:www.w.org  svg viewBox  . %E%C svg%E" Mrs May will lobby the EU to fix the withdrawal agreement by removing the hated Irish backstop proposal.If she succeeds, Brexiteer Tories will almost certainly pile in behind her and approval the new-look deal within weeks.She will also have a chance of successBrussels gives her half a victory - placing new limits on the backstop, but without removing it altogether.Butthe EU plays hardball and refuses to renegotiate the deal, Mrs May faces a game of chicken with rebellious MPs.The PM could press ahead and try to get approval for her deal as it stands - risking a chaotic No Deal Brexitthe Eurosceptics hold firm.Or she could work with Labour to cut a Soft Brexit deal which keeps Britain in the customs union.That would probably lead to a deal - but would enrage Tory backbenchers who would see it as a sell-out.Another possibility is that pro-Remain MPs would launch a new bid to seize control of the timetable by voting to delay Brexit in order to rule out No Deal.That would plunge Britain into months of fresh uncertainty with the possible outcomes including a snap General Election or a second referendum.

title: leavers remainers together uk flourish brexit
story: We all want certainty that we will be leaving the EU on th March.  That would enable us all to plan for le beyond Brexit and lead to a period of political calm.The Government’s deal has been rejected by Parliament.  Therefore, leavers and remainers need to come together to develop a new plan so that we can deliver the referendum result and ensure that we flourish outside the EU.This is exactly what we have tried to do with the help of Kit Malthouse. Nicky Morgan, Robert Buckland and Stephen Hammond were on dferent sides to me and Steve Baker during the referendum.  But we have decided to put our dferences aside and unite to publish a new proposal on how we should leave the EU.Leavers rejected the Government’s EU deal because the backstop would have stopped us from agreeing trade deals. So, we have suggested replacing the backstop with a new protocol that solves the concerns people have about the Irish border and which protects the Union of the United Kingdom.Remainers want a guaranteed Implementation Period – a period which allows us all to adjust to le beyond the EU.  Our plan offers a smooth transition with an additional year of the Implementation Period, making it last until no later than the end of December .Parliament, our country and the  member states of the EU are united in wanting a deal and this proposal can pass through Parliament and restore Government unity, purpose and direction.If the EU ignores this consensus, we have proposed a Plan B – a “triple safety net” to protect us.  It includes cooperation on security, a guarantee by the UK of zero tarfs, no quantitative restrictions and no new trading barriers, along with a generous offer to pay our financial contributions infor an Implementation Period.These proposals would allow everyone to prepare fully for the UK leaving the EU and gives us the space to have proper trade talks so that we can develop a close trading relationship  – which, after all, is what Brexit was supposed to be about.Millions of people voted to leave the EU so that we could become an outward- looking, strong, free-trading nation.They also wanted us to maintain the closest of friendships with our allies on the continent, to continue to trade closely with our European counterparts and to let EU citizens - who have become our friends and neighbours and made the UK their home - feel welcome here.We can still be proud of our shared European heritage after leaving the EU but we must do this as an independent nation.This plan gives us a way of doing this and we invite everyone across the House of Commons and the country to support us as we forge a deal that brings the whole country together.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nostalgic snaps show middle class brits keeping calm and carrying on
story: From snaps of a schoolboy working on his homework to a smartly-dressed family sitting at the dinner table, the vintage snaps give a glimpse into what it was like after WW.Others show carefree kids playing outside on their bikes and go-karts on the quiet streets, and an orderly queue waiting for a double-decker bus.Despite only being  years ago, lots has changed in st century Britain -  marriages lasted longer and orces were typically frowned upon.There were , orces in Britain in  compared with , in .And in , there were , broken marriages.At the time it was rare for the woman of the house to have her own occupation and she was usually expected to play the role of ‘model we’, whilst the husband went to work.Only around one third of women had a job.And as far as babies were concerned,  percent of children were born out of wedlock - compared with nearly  per cent of children born in the UK today.By , British prime minister Harold Macmillan even famously informed his party colleagues that most of our people have never had it so good.Although the hangover from the war played its part in the course of the s, average salaries more than doubled but inflation remained around the three per cent.This particular middle class family appears to enjoy a comfortable standard of living but across the UK, the picture was not always so rosy.Years of war had ravaged the country’s industry, housing stock and greenspaces and left a legacy of high taxation.Nearly half the population made do with private rented accommodation – often in cramped conditions with little comfort or warmth. Half of the UK’s homes had no indoor bathroom.Because of the Second World War, Brits couldnt enjoy treats like canned fruit, chocolate biscuits and mincemeat until May .Those craving a bacon sarnie would have to wait another four years before enjoying the British favourite.

title: bbc took weeks choose bricks
story: NewsBBC took weeks to choose BRICKS for new EastEnders set as cost spiralled by £mThe surprising admission came as BBC chiefs were quizzed on a staggering £million cost overrun for the new Albert SquareShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video bbc-took-weeks-choose-bricks-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get soaps updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe BBC took weeks to choose bricks for the new EastEnders set, Westminster’s powerful spending watchdog heard tonight. Corporation bosses were hauled before the Commons Public Account Committee to explain a staggering poundmillion cost overrun for the E project, creating the soap’s Albert Square.During the -minute hearing, Labour ’s Chris Evans tackled BBC Content’s chief operating officer Richard Dawkins over specications for the project.Quizzing the broadcasting executive over an apparent delay between the BBC and contractor Wates in selecting raw materials, the MP said: “There seems to be an issue with bricks.” Mr Dawkins confirmed: “Before going into contract, we felt it was important to look at a range of dferent types of brick and, very importantly, bring in our production colleagues to review those bricks themselves given, ultimately, they’re the ones who will be operating the set.  “We did that in advance of letting the contract with Wates. “The objective for the ‘front lot’ is to replicate the existing Albert Square site - making sure we have that right was really important.” In a bizarre exchange which could have come straight from “mockumentary” WA, Mr Dawkins admitted the selection process took “weeks”. Baffled Mr Evans said: “Wouldn’t it have been easier just to go to a DIY shop and compare them ” But the BBC boss hit back: “It’s quite important that we replicate the look and feel of Walford and Albert Square. “It’s Victorian era, it’s an extensive build around the entire Square, so this is really important.”  He insisted: “If you look at the current set there are dferent shades of brick. “This is not just about going and finding off your local DIY store a limited choice. “It was the right thing to do.” The E project to rebuild the soap’s HQ in Elstree, Herts is costing licence fee payers a staggering poundmillion rather than the poundmillion originally planned. It will not be finished until . Mr Evans suggested EastEenders could have followed rival Emmerdale’s example. The ITV soap staged a plane crash two decades ago and revamped its set. “Obviously there’s the example of Emmerdale in the ‘s who flew a fictional aeroplane into... and they wiped out the cast and the set and rebuilt it,” said Mr Evans. “Would it be cheaper through a plot line to have something fall out of the sky fictionally and wipe out the EastEnders set and rebuild it as new ” Lord Hall said: “ I think we are now in WA territory ... but no is the answer.” Asking the peer what lessons the BBC had learned, the MP asked: “Apart from dropping a bomb on the set, what would you dferently ” Lord Hall said: “I think we have got the right team together but leadership is important.” He also blamed the discovery of asbestos for the spiralling cost.

title: brexit barclays wins permission transfer
story: NewsBrexit: Barclays wins permission to transfer £BILLION in assets to IrelandIts so they can "continue to serve our clients within the EU beyond March  "ShareCommentsByRavender Sembhy:,  JAN NewsThe banking giant received approval from the High Court "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBarclays has been given the green light to transfer  billion eurosworth of assets to Ireland. The banking giant received approval from the High Court on Wednesday for the move, which involves , clients.It comes as the company ramps up its Brexit contingency planning.As we announced in , Barclays will use our existing licensed EU-based bank subsidiary to continue to serve our clients within the EU beyond March   regardless of the outcome of Brexit, the bank said. Our preparations are well-advanced and we expect to be fully operational by March  . The move is designed to deal with the consequences of a no-deal hard Brexit, in which UK based banks would lose passporting rights that allow them toin the EUs single market, the worlds richest trading bloc.   In approving the move, Mr Justice Snowden said in his judgment: Due to the continuing uncertainty over whether there might be a no-deal Brexit, the Barclays Group has determined that it cannot wait any longer to implement the scheme. In light of the large volume of business to be transferred, the scheme contains a number of phased dates upon which the transfer of the dferent types of business, and the business of the branches in Spain, Italy and France, will become effective. The overriding requirement, however, is that BBImust be legally and operationally ready to conduct all relevant regulated business with the in-scope clients by no later than March  , which is the date currently set for Brexit. Several banks - including the Royal Bank of Scotland, Lloyds, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and a host of others - have set up continental hubs in preparation for Britains exit from the EU. This involves hundreds of jobs and hundreds of billions in assets being shted out of London, hitting the Treasurys tax revenue and denting the capitals reputation as a financial centre. Frankfurt, Germanys financial capital, is one of the biggest beneficiaries of Brexit. For its part, Barclays will increase its Dublin headcount by around  to  as a result of Brexit.

title: brexit major companies leaving uk
story: NewsBrexit: All the major companies leaving the UK to avoid chaos as the clock ticks downThe British Chambers of Commerce has warned that the preparations by its members so far only represented the “tip of the iceberg”ShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsTheresa May on a visit to a factory"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor many months the idea that businesses might leave the UK because of Brexit was dismissed as project fear. But as the days to Brexit tick down, more and more companies are choosing to move their headquarters, move jobs or leave the UK altogether. The British Chambers of Commerce has warned that the preparations by its members so far only represented the “tip of the iceberg” and that many of its , members were already spending funds to prepare for a no deal exit.Banks and financial services are worried that a disorderly Brexit could see banks lose passporting rights that allow direct access to clients in the EU. Labour MP Yvette Cooper told the Observer two major employers in her West Yorkshire constituency - luxury goods manufacturer Burberry and confectioner Haribo - had both written to her, warning of the damaging effects of no deal on their UK operations. Burberry employs  people in Castleford, and Haribo  across her constituency.Accountancy firm KPMG reports that many of the businesses they have spoken to are praying for an extension to article .   Companies moving their HQ out of the UK or opening new branches in Europe: Unilever The consumer goods giant was almost first out of the starting gate when it came to making a move. It chose Rotterdam over London for its headquarters but insisted that the move was not due to Brexit. The Anglo-Dutch company was former in the s when Dutch margarine firm Unie merged with British soap maker Lever Brothers.  Despite personally supporting Brexit, James Dyson revealed that he is moving the HQ of his vacuum-cleaner firm to Singapore. The move means Dyson is no longer a British registered company and Singapore will become its main tax base. It is the second blow Dyson has dealt to Brexit Britain after last years announcement that it will manufacturer its new electric cars in Singapore, rather than the UK. The tycoon was one of the few businessmen to back Brexit and has now been accused of staggering hypocrisy. Easyjet Easyjet also made an early move. It has set up a new company in Austria to protect its European business after Brexit. The new airline, EasyJet Europe, will be based in Vienna. The airline must have an air operator certicate in an EU member country to allow it to continue flying between member states after Brexit. Sony  Sony confirmed it is moving its European headquarters from London to Amsterdam. But it insisted that it would not move personnel and operations from the existing UK operations. It is just the latest Japanese company to talk of moves to the continent.   Lloyds of London Insurance and reinsurance market Lloyds of London announced in May that it had received regulatory approval from the National Bank of Belgium to establish an insurance company in Brussels. Those threatening to go: Airbus  Chief executive Tom Enders issued a naked threat to leave the UK by warning it was madness to assume the firm will stay. In a direct warning to the government he said: If theres a no-deal Brexit, we at Airbus will have to make potentially very harmful decisions for the UK. Aerospace is Europes largest aerospace manufacturer, which employs , people in the UK and supports another , through supply chains.   Muji Japanese retailer Muji isrumoured to be moving its European HQ from the UK to Germany. Those who have moved jobs out of the UK: HSBC  The bank has said it is on course to move up to , jobs to France. Goldman Sachs The bank - which employs , UK staff - is set to at least double its Frankfurt workforce to . Barclays The bank expects a small number of roles to move from London to Europe, with most heading to Dublin. Those who have reduced production: Toyota   The car maker has warned that a no-deal Brexit would put production of poundm worth of cars a day at risk. The company has said it would put its Deeside and Burnaston plants on “stop-start” production for weeks or months, putting jobs and wages in jeopardy.   Honda The company has planned a six day halt in April to plan for all possible outcomes caused by logistics and border issues. And other Brexit consequences: Bentley The chief executive of Bentley said the company was stockpiling parts. He described Brexit as a “killer” threatening the profitability of the luxury carmaker. PO  The ferry company announced that its fleet of cross-Channel ferries will be re-registered under the Cypriot flag .The company said they were taking the decision ahead of Britains departure to keeptax arrangements in the EU. It will also mean fewer inspections and delays.

title: brexit what happens now after
story: NewsAnalysisBrexit: What happens now after EU chiefs reject Theresa Mays new planBrussels chiefs said "No, Non, Nein" to Theresa Mays new Brexit plan - so here is what happens nextShareByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  JAN NewsAnalysisThe Prime Minister met a wall of resistance from the EU’s top politicians "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrussels chiefs have lined up today to say “No, Non, Nein” to Theresa May’s bid to reopen the Brexit deal. The Prime Minister met a wall of resistance from the EU’s top politicians who insisted the withdrawal agreement could not be unpicked. Senior figures in Brussels, Berlin, Paris and Dublin all warned that her demand increased the chances of no-deal Brexit as the clock ticks down towards March . Mrs May has admitted there is “little appetite” for reopening a deal in EU capitals, but has been instructed by MPs to try to strike a Plan B. She is desperately trying to hold together a fragile truce in the Tory ranks after a vote on Tuesday demanded the hated Irish backstop was replaced with “alternative arrangements”. So where do things go from here  Weve spoken to sources who are plotting the way forward.  The PM and her ministers will spend the next few days working out exactly what to take back to Brussels. Mrs May has already held talks with Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, Irish PM Leo Varadker and EU chief Donald Tusk. She will now try to nail down the detail of her Plan B. Some Tory MPs thought the Brady amendment just meant a few tweaks on the Irish border backstop plan. But many Brexiteers only backed it on the understanding she would rip up the withdrawal agreement altogether. She will meet with some of those backbenchers on Thursday. As well as trying to hold together the Tory party’s fragile truce, the also needs to push key EU figures as far as they will go.  Mrs May is expected to jet out to Brussels early next week after, as one No  insider put it, “the howling stops and the dust settles”. Government insiders are not optimistic about their chances of persuading Brussels to reopen the orce deal after EU leaders lined up to say “Non. Nein. Nej.” But they’re keeping their fingers crossed that the EU might have one last big compromise up its sleeve. Even the PM admitted it would be a big ask. But in order to deliver on Parliament’s wishesshe has to at least try. She is looking at three areas for the backstop - technological solutions, a time limit and a unilateral exit clause - all of which she has said would be impossible in the past.  The Government has promised thatit gets a deal, MPs will get a second ‘meaningful vote’ on her revised Brexit plan as soon as possible. If, as expected, Brussels rejects her pleas and she comes home empty handed, they will be given a fresh chance to debate Brexit on February  with a vote the next day. This will give MPs the chance to re-run this week’s amendmentsthey wish - potentially handing back control of the Brexit process to Parliament, delaying the UK’s departure beyond March  or legally ruling out crashing out altogether. Mrs May promised another set of votes - which she hopes will not turn into a Valentines’ Day massacre - to stave off a Remainer rebellion on Tuesday. WHAT NOW FOR BREXIT   Unless Brussels puts a last minute offer on the table, which looks unlikely, Mrs May will be back at the despatch box in two weeks’ time. Her party will be more ided than ever. Tory Brexiteers and the DUP will be pushing her to the next stage of the ‘Malthouse compromise’ which would ultimately mean leaving the EU a year later and on damaging WTO terms. Her Remainer MPs who stuck by her this time will be in no mood for standing quietly by. They will push her towards a softer Brexit - working with Labour MPs to get a deal that Brussels would accept. After years of kicking decisions down the road, it will finally be decision day for the PM - continue to appease her hardline Brexiteers, or work across the Commons in the national interest, but risk splitting her party.

story: NewsNo Deal Brexit is now more likely than ever, EU chiefs brutally declareMichel Barnier joined Ireland in brutally refusing Theresa Mays bid to reopen talks on the -page Brexit dealShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video michel-barnier-says-eu-preparing-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA No Deal Brexit is now more likely than ever, chiefs of the EU have declared in a brutal warning to the UK. Michel Barnier and Jean-Claude Juncker gave defiant speeches today as they savaged Theresa Mays demand to re-open the -page Brexit deal. MPs backed the Prime Ministers strategy to re-open talks last night - giving her a mandate toto Brussels. But EU chief negotiator Mr Barnier said  days before Brexit, he will not restart talks - because MPs still hadnt voted for anything that will actually work. Demanding ludicity and realism and accusing the UK of a blame game, he told the European Parliament: We share the will of the UK Parliament to avoid a no deal. [But] voting against a No Deal, as happened yesterday, does not rule out the risk of a No Deal. Jean-Claude Juncker, the European Commission President, added: I will listen to her ideas, but I will also be extremely clear about the position of the EU.   Yesterdays vote has further increased the risk of a disorderly exit of the UK. We have tried everything in our power to prepare for all scenarios, including the worst. Mr Barnier backed up the warning by saying no-deal preparations were now more essential than ever. He told MEPs: I mentioned lucidity and realism.  Its less than  days now to when the UK is going to leave, but we dont have a positive majority in the House of Commons on a clearly identied solution accepted by the UK. It is therefore urgent that we should be prepared for all scenarios and bring in all contingency measures, which are more essential than ever. The EU is offering to add guarantees to the small political declaration spelling out future trade. But Mr Barnier refused to change the Withdrawal Agreement - they key document that contains the backstop. Former Ukip leader Nigel Farage said the prospect of a no-deal Brexit had increased because of the attitude of Brussels fanatics who refused to compromise. He said Mrs May now realised the mistake made in agreeing to the backstop, adding: She signed up to something that no country - unless it had been defeated in war - would have signed up to. There was now an appreciation in Britain that unelected bureaucrats in Brussels have been talking down to and humiliating the Prime Minister of our nation, and we dont like it. He added: Many will say we are simply dealing with fanatics who are not prepared to be reasonable and make any sense of compromise.  Theresa May got MPs approval last night to seek either a time limit, an exit clause or alternative arrangements to the backstop. But Mr Barnier fumed: The backstop is part and parcel of the Withdrawal Agreement and this agreement will not be renegotiated. We need this backstop as it is.   Rejecting the backstop as it stands today boils down to rejecting the solution which was found with the British. He added: The European Council and the European Parliament, on several occasions, have already clearly rejected the idea of having a limit in time or leaving unilaterally. Because that would undermine the very idea of the backstop. title: theresa mays brexit victory not
story: NewsopinionTheresa Mays Brexit victory is not quite what you thinkSanity is beginning to reassert itself, in the place where dreams meet geographyShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JAN Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Hooray and huzzah, hang out the bunting and issue high-fives all round. Something has finally happened on Brexit.What has happened is that the Tories have agreed to stop screaming up their own bumholes and scream at the EU instead. This will come as a relief to all those who witnessed their -month act of circular self-abuse, but they did at least give us a new definition for windbags.  This has been described as Theresa Mays best day at work since  by all those people who have not had enough fresh air recently. Her great success is that someone  has been able to unite the Tories around a version of Brexit that is impossible, impractical and undeliverable.They even managed to persuade  of the crazier members of the Labour Party to join them in this unmedicated dreamland, where the DUP have long gambolled in the insane belief it will reignite their holy war against the Fenians.The Tories have, for the first time in two and a half years, decided what they want. The problem is that it is the opposite of what Theresa has done or can do. On November , , she told the House of Commons: The Brexit talks are about acting in the national interest, and that means making what I believe to be the right choices, not the easy ones.I know there are some who have said I should simply rip up the UK’s commitment to a backstop, but this would have been an entirelyirresponsible course of action. It would have meant reneging on a promise made to the people of Northern Ireland during the referendum campaign and afterwards - that under no circumstances would Brexit lead to ato the borders of the past - and it would have made it impossible to deliver a withdrawal agreement.As Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, I have a responsibility to people in every part of our country, and I intend to honour that promise.And last night, she was told to do all the things she didnt want to do on the grounds that doing them would be f***ing disastrous. What has happened is this: . Theresa presented Plan A, which guaranteed the rights and safety of .m British citizens in Northern Ireland, and was punched in the face by Parliament which snarled stuff em.. Theresa presented Plan B, which was much the same but had a dferent letter on the front page, and Parliament said well maybe so long as we can decide to say stuff em later, slapped Theresa lightly and sent her back to Brussels. The EU are about to say alors, but you people cest tres thick. Theresas people are already briefing therell be a Plan C. And I can tell you now whats in it.  Plan C will have moved on signicantly from Plan B by being more like Plan A. Itll have the same words in much the same order, with very similar promises about protecting those .m British citizens with a backstop, and it will get voted through by Parliament for two reasons.First, theyve voted on it twice already, and have been dragged towards accepting a version of it. On the third time of asking, theyll be ready to back ANY version, in much the same way a man who has kicked himself in the head will wonderits possible to do it again.Imagine such a person, and you will have invented Iain Duncan Smith.  Secondly, there will be no other option.There is now no Parliamentary time left for Theresas deal to get the necessary legislation through before its self-imposed Article  deadline. There isnt even enough time for the new laws we need to trade under WTO rules in the event of a No Deal Brexit.By automatic operation of the law, on March  all EU treaties cease to be effective. Predicted results include motorways turning into lorry parks, medicines being rationed, the imposition of martial law and Jacob Rees-Mogg declaring an ancestral right to eat peasants. Even those Parliamentarians whove been hoarding gold and have a Barbudan bolthole dont want that sort of legacy hung around their neck, so extending the deadline is inevitable. And fortunately, the law they wrote about all this allows for a minister to change the exit date whenever they fancy. And most importantly there is no other option for the border in Northern Ireland. No way to take back control, no way to superimpose a UK referendum on to a people who had a referendum on this already, and managed a % mandate on an % turnout. People traffickers and drug smugglers dont fill in customs forms, weve no way to police a -mile border with  crossing points, and as the cherry on the cake elderly IRA bombers are coming out of retirement to make car bombs for new splinter groups.The only way all these things were resolved was with an open border, that allowed the unionists to remain British while allowing the republicans to pretend they were Irish.No-one has an alternative to that, and it is a fact of quite beautul irony that the only way anyones going to Brexit isthey refuse to take back control of our sole land border with the EU.So we wont Brexit on March , because we cant. Well call it Brexit a bit later, and it wont be because all this arguing was just to get us to the point where we could discuss what Brexit will look like. And it wont ever BE Brexit, because every power-crazed demand the backbench fruitloops have made has had to be dropped - when courts ruled it unlawful, when public opinion swung against them, and when Theresa persisted them into submission.Her problem is that all the Brexit chaos has been laid at her door. She has been blamed for the indecision, poor negotiation and infighting, for a dud election and international humiliation.Yet somehow, through either great stupidity or brilliant stratagem, she has forced her party and the country to agree what it never would have done in , a year or even  months ago. Leavers and Remainers now fervently believe any deal is better than none at all, appreciate Northern Irelands problems in a way few ever bothered to do, andthe polls are right are coming to the opinion that the current deal we have with the EU is the best of all possible worlds.What happened last night is that the hardliners have taken their latest of , tiny steps towards admitting their dream is just that. Thats why Theresa is stronger than ever, why the Labour Party is on the back foot and the EU is scratching its head.Sanity is beginning to reassert itself. It says do something, avert disaster, extract cranium from bum, ask yourselfthis is a good idea. All those Parliamentarians who complained Parliament was being undemocratic are now praising it for embodying the will of the people.Theres months and probably years more of arseing about, of course, and any group of people with a fetish for rectal screaming are probably going to try it a few times more before they realise it hurts too much.Sanity is not immediate. But it is there, flickering gently in the place where dreams meet geography.

story: NewsAmber Peat inquest: Girl, , found hanged was scared to go home from schoolAmber was found hanged in bushes three days after she went missing from her home in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, an inquest has heardShareBySophie Evans:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAmber Peat was sometimes concerned about going home, an inquest has heard "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA missing -year-old girl who was found hanged was sometimes concerned about going home from school, an inquest has heard. Amber Peat was found sitting in the library, filled with worry, on one occasion after losing the belt from her coat, the hearing was told. Teacher Joanne Holland described how she had to call the youngsters mum because she was scared of going home and getting told off. During the phone conversation, Mrs Holland assured Ambers mother: We will find it, Nottinghamshire Coroners Court heard this week. She was worried about going home because she had lost the belt off her coat, the teacher told the court, according to the BBC. She basically said she was scared she was going to get told off. I had to phone home and tell mum, It really is fine, we will find it.   The encounter happened at the end of the school day, it was said. Amber was found hanged in  three days after she went missing from her home, following a row with her mum over household chores. The court has heard the argument was about cleaning a cool box, which was used to store food on a recent family holiday in Cornwall, where the youngster had hatched plans to run away with her cousin. Ambers mother Kelly Peat heard the front door slam shut shortly after the dispute at around .pm on May , , at the home in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, the inquest had been told. A passer-by saw somebody of Ambers description enter a hedgerow area near the address around  minutes later, it was said.  Up to  police staff were involved in the search for the missing youngster, before her body was tragically recovered on June . Speaking at the inquest, Mrs Holland, an ex-form tutor of Amber, described how the schoolgirl often tried to get attention. The teacher said she felt this could be because the student didnt get as much attention at home as would be considered normal. She recalled the youngsters habit of leaving an item behind after form time, so she couldto the classroom to retrieve it. She said she liked walking into a room filled with older students. Obviously the older students, because she was small and cute, were like, aww, look at Amber and she would love that, said Mrs Holland.  The teacher had been Ambers form tutor at Tibshelf Community School, but the pupil left the school before the end of her first year. Instead, she moved to Queen Elizabeth School in Mansfield . Another teacher has told the inquest that she didnt want to move. Before she vanished from her home before her death, the teenager had got into trouble for drinking Cherryade without permission. She had a history of running away, and Mrs Peat only called police to report her missing at .am on May , the inquest has heard. Detective Constable Tina Gilfoyle, of Nottinghamshire Police, said the mum and Ambers stepfather, Danny Peat, had been to Tesco and had tea while the youngster was missing.   Providing background of the the teenagers disappearance, Ms Gilfoyle said the family had moved  times in Ambers letime. The hearing has been told there was no evidence of physical neglect and no sign Amber was malnourished at the time of her death. Home Office pathologist Frances Hollingbury said there were no traces of alcohol or drugs in her body and no suggestion of a mental illness. A post-mortem found no evidence to suggest anyone  was involved. The inquest continues. If you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling   or byemailingjo@samaritans.org

title: dinner tea lunch dinner etiquette
story: NewsIf you say tea instead of dinner youve been making a big mistake your whole leAn etiquette expert has revealed the correct names for the three main meals of the day and some of you have been saying it wrongShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAn etiquette expert has finally solved a big food debate"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email What you call the dferent meals of the day will depend partly on where in the world youre from.Some people use the word dinner when they mean lunch, others use the word tea instead of dinner. But thankfully we now know for sure what the proper names for each of the three main meals are - and it might surprise you to learn youve been saying it wrong your entire le.  Etiquette expert William Hanson, explained all to The Sun Online.He said: The correct order of meals is breakfast, lunch or luncheon as it is technically called, and then dinner. Soyouve ever referred to your evening meal as tea, youve been making a big etiquette mistake. William went on to reveal that tea should only be used to describe times around midday and early evening when you sit down and enjoy afternoon tea, with smaller snacks such as finger sandwiches and scones.  Despite the issue now being cleared up once and for all, a number of people are still debating the correct phrasing on Twitter.Some people were quick to point out that a school dinner is traditionally served at midday, and isnt called lunch, while those who serve up the food are also know as dinner ladies.Others referenced how Christmas dinners can be eaten at any time during the day.A dferent user revealed that they use neither dinner or tea, but instead refer to their meal as supper.   Another added that they simply call all food scran. However one person wasnt having any of the nonsense and reminded people outright that: You drink tea, you dont eat it. story: NewsDog owners clock up an astonishing  miles a year walking their petThe animal lovers put in more than  miles a week on average while out for a stroll with their poochShareCommentsByGemma Francis:,  JAN NewsExperts say dog owners enjoy improved mental health and reduced stress levels while walking their pooches "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDog owners trek  miles a year - just while walking their pet, a study has found. story: NewsMan, , becomes male Mrs Hinch with top social media cleaning tipsCurtis Kelly, , from County Down, Northern Ireland, is making waves on social media with his @cleanwithme Instagram account - and has revealed his number one cleaning tipShareCommentsByShauna CorrAmber Hicks:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video -year-old-lad-giving-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old lad is fast becoming the male ‘Mrs Hinch’ after a broken back inspired him to share his cleaning tips on social media. In just three weeks, Curtis Kelly has gained more than , followers on his @Cleanwithme Instagram account and counts the clean queen herself Mrs Hinch among his fans. He was inspired by the phenomenon Sophie Hinchclfe, who has .million followers, has appeared on This Morning and is releasing her own book, Hinch Yourself Happy, in April. And he might soon be giving the Essex hairdresser a run for her money with his before and after photo transformations. Curtis, who lives with is mum in Newtownards, Northern Ireland, “never ever expected” his mopping, scrubbing and hoovering stories would be such an inspiration to others, some who have credited him for helping them with depression.  The care worker told Belfast Live : “I broke my spine nine weeks ago and I thought to myself, ‘I’ll start an Instagram and it’ll just be something to do when I’m off work’. “I was putting up some Christmas lights and fell off a ladder straight on to the concrete. It was terrible. “When I was taken to AE in a neck brace, there was a question as to whether I would walk again as they were doing nerve tests and I couldn’t feel.” Thankfully, his feeling ed in a “couple of hours”.   “I am incredibly grateful and a lucky person to be able to come back from an injury like that,” he added. “I fractured three vertebrae in my back, which was agony.” Curtis was then “laid up for four weeks” and wasn’t allowed to drive. “When I was back up on my feet that’s when the Instagram came because I was bored on my own every day,” he said. “I just needed something.”   But Curtis said he never expected his page to take off, never mind inspire others facing their own troubles. He said: “It’s just exploded out of nowhere. “It’s a massive shock. It was a wee bit of fun, but it’s just escalated. “ Mrs Hinch follows my page and she messages me. I have always loved cleaning and when I saw her making her Instagram account, I thought ‘why not ’ to give me something to do.  “My Instagram account is to inspire and help people and show them my wee cleaning tips and the hacks that I do. “My mum tells me that from no age I was running about the house with my little cleaning trolly cleaning up behind people,” said Curtis. “It’s just something I have always been into and I take a lot of pride in having a clean house.” But he said “it came as a bit of a surprise” when people started reaching out to him.   “I thought people might watch and have a laugh at me cleaning as I dance about the house like a mad man,” he added. “I just didn’t think I’d become such an inspiration to people. I never ever expected that and I wouldn’t change it for the world. “I have had so many messages daily. There was one woman who told me she was depressed when her partner died years ago and she hadn’t touched his clothes. “I did a video where I cleared my wardrobe and sort of keeping sentimental things, but I put them in boxes somewhere.   “She said ‘I’m glad you did that, because it gave me the push I needed’. “It’s amazing getting messages from people saying I help them fight anxiety and depression, that, for me, makes it so worth it. While his videos are all about leaving making sure the house he shares with his mother is gleaming, they have also helped a Ballybeen woman with depression and anxiety, to get out of bed in the mornings.   The woman, who did not want to be named, said: “He is just amazing. “I live on my own and some days with my depression and social anxiety I can’t even get out the door or even get out of bed. But when I switch on my Instagram, I watch him and Mrs Hinch and they are just enough for me to just get up out of bed and do even the tiniest wee thing like making my bed and sitting in the living room. “They can inspire me to do that. They just make me feel that little bit more human.”   Meanwhile, Curtis has revealed his number one cleaning tip. Get music on when you’re cleaning, he said. “I stick the music on and dance about the house and do each room one at a time. Just have fun with it. It’s not the funnest thing to do and a lot of people don’t enjoy it like I do. “But when you do it one room at a time and get your favourite play list or artist on, it just makes it so much easier.”

story: NewsNew study reveals what workers want most from their employersMore than half also want their staff benefits to help improve their work-le balanceShareCommentsByEmma Elsworthy:,  JAN NewsAccess to mental health care is also important to those who started working this decade "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFlexible working hours, more pension contributions – and extra holiday for long service are among the top work perks British employees want, according to a survey. A study of , workers found more than half want their staff benefits to help improve their work le balance and  per cent want added extras which will save them money. And while younger adults highlight the need for help with housing, older generations are more concerned with private healthcare. Access to mental health care is also more important to those who started working this decade than to those who began their careers in any decade before.   It also emerged fewer than one in five are currently totally satisfied with the benefits package provided by their employer. And half of employees would leave their current employmentthey thought they could get a position where with more perks, with just  per cent preferring extra pay over comprehensive benefits. Steven Osei, spokesman for the Preferential Partnerships programme at Get Living, said: It’s no surprise that employees’ attitudes to workplace benefits have changed over the last five decades since the world we live in is almost unrecognisable now. “Employees are moving jobs more often, increasingly working from home and expecting to be compensated for their dedication. “To keep up with the competition, employers need to reflect workers more flexible lestyles.” The study also revealed employees who started their working le in  or later are most likely to want pets in the office, and free breakfast supplies. And the demand for company-expensed dental care has decreased over the decades, with nearly a quarter of older workers feeling it should be offered as standard by employers. This compares to just nine per cent of people who started their careers during this decade. Free tea and coffee is most valued by workers aged between -, with over-s the most likely to seek out an enhanced pension contribution.   People aged between - cite unlimited holiday days as the most attractive perk they think a company could offer. It also emerged employees who have been working the longest are most satisfied with their current benefits package, with those starting work in the s the least happy. Although more people who started work during this decade are currently looking for a job with better benefits than any other workers. But unusually, younger workers are also most likely to stay in their jobs because the benefits are too good to pass up.More than six in  workers who took part in the survey, conducted through OnePoll , believe their employer has a responsibility to look after their personal well-being.And workers agree they have become more demanding of their employers due to the hours spent at work, increased retirement age and the always-on nature of work making them feel their companies should offer more for their service. Get Living works with employers through its Preferential Partnerships programme to learn the challenges their people face living and commuting in the city where they work and offer a better way of renting. So why is it there still stigma associated with the breed  According to the Dogs Trust its partly down to the dogs fighting history which has tarnished the breed with the dangerous dog label, as well as their muscular appearance. A spokesperson for the charity told : There are lots of misconceptions and myths around theStaffordshire Bull Terrier, probablydue to their stocky and muscular appearance.However, it’s important to remember that there is greater iation in behavioural characteristics within breeds than between them - so we cant judge a dog by its appearance any more than a book by its cover.As with any breed of dog, the majority of Staffies are amazing, happy, friendly and fun members of the family - behaviouralproblems only arise where they dont have good early le socialisation, consistent interactions and positive training. The charity said it often sees a lot of Staffies at their centres due to over-breeding, or dogs being handed in by people who may not have realised how much care and attention they really need. Last year  Staffies and Staffie crosses were adopted across the Dogs Trusts network of rehoming centres. We see first-hand the positive dference these dogs make to their owners lives, sowe were delighted to see this breed crowned as the nations favourite, Dogs Trust added.We hope this boost for Staffies will encourage people to embrace the affectionate and loyal qualities that we know are so true of the breed. For anyone looking to adopt a Staffie, the Dogs Trust currently has  from puppies to OAPs  who are all hoping to head off to their forever homes very soon.

story: NewsMan uses child as human de-icer to clear snow from his car windscreenThe man and child, who are both dressed ready for the weather in coats, gloves and hats, are both laughingShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video dad-uses-son-defrost-car-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A man has been filmed using a child as a human de-icer to clear the snow from his car.The clip, which has been widely shared on social media, shows the man picking the child up and putting him on the top of the black car. He then drags him down across the rear window clearing the ice. The man and child, who are covered in snow, are both laughing and the child can be heard squealing with excitement.Both are wrapped up ready for the cold in coats, gloves and hats.  The man then picks the child up again and carries him to the front window and repeats the same. title: fresh or frozen teles lindsey has taste test ahead of planned changes to dundee school meals
story: The Tele#s story last week that Tayside schoolchildren could soon be eating frozen school dinners instead of fresh meals prepared in city schools provoked a strong response online.Some readers were unsure  Dundee City Council should go ahead with plans to change its school meal provision from cooking on site to cooking them at a central hub and distributing them to schools.Read here for the full story.One of the concerns was that frozen food might taste worse than freshly-made meals.Rather than speculate, Tele reporter Lindsey Hamilton had a taste test at Perth City Chambers to compare the dference between frozen and freshly-made lentil soup.The video is at the top of this article. Lindsey#s account is below.I was very interested to take part in the blind taste test.I had no ideaI would be able to tell the dference between the fresh and the frozen food.As it turned out I got it wrong  but interestingly I preferred the fresh food.However, it would be fair to say that both sets of food were very tasty.Had I not known that one set of food was frozen and one was freshly prepared that morning I doubt very muchI could have found a dference.I believed that the food I preferred  was frozen but not sure why # I think it had something to do with the custard seeming thinner.I have a perception that food of that type once defrosted is thinner – don’t ask me why!The frozen food was tasty, looked and smelt good and had a nice consistency – and I was ensured it was probably even more nutritious than the freshly prepared dishes.For my personal taste however, the freshly prepared food had the edge – it seemed creamier, better seasoned and I suppose fresher!However, I wouldn’t turn my nose up at the frozen food – and having taken part in the experiment I don’t think our pupils or their parents have very much to worry about – school dinners rule!

title: ivan golac returning to dundee united for hall of fame induction
story: Dundee United’s original Scottish Cup legend Ivan Golac will be back at Tannadice next month when he’s to be inducted in the club’s Hall of Fame.The man with the magic hat famously led the Tangerines to their first-ever Scottish Cup success when he led them to a shock victory over Rangers at Hampden in .Ending United’s Hampden hoodoo that had seen them lose their previous six finals and his flamboyant managerial style made Golac an instant hero.And now the club are recognising his contribution to their history by adding him to their Hall of Fame.His name will join the likes of Doug Smith, Dave Narey, Paul Hegarty and Jim McLean on the roll of honour.Also being inducted this year is former player Tommy Neilson, along with two others whose names are still to be revealed.The Hall of Fame Dinner takes place in the West End Lounge at Tannadice on February .

title: jesse curran to miss dundees scottish cup replay at queen of the south
story: Midfielder Jesse Curran will miss Dundee’s Scottish Cup replay at Queen of the South today because of the hamstring injury he suffered in Saturday’s defeat against Motherwell.The Dark Blues are assessing the problem that saw Curran pull up with just five minutes on the clock at Dens Park.However, the fear is the Australian, who was limping heavily as he headed for the dressing-room after watching the first half from the bench, could be sidelined for several weeks.That would be a major blow for both boss Jim McIntyre and the -year-old who has made  appearances in an excellent first campaign as a top-team regular.Curran’s form has seen him monitored by his home country’s national team while Philippines manager Sven-Goran Eriksson has offered him the chance to be part of their set-up.He qualies for them through his mother and is also eligible for Scotland, where his father was born.“The physio is assessing Jesse and we’ll just have to see how he is,” said his club boss.Jim was left frustrated by the single-goal defeat against ’Well that came courtesy of a second-half penalty from David Turnbull, following a rash Ryan Inniss tackle on Elliot Frear.The gaffer, though, took consolation from the way his side dominated most of the play.“To say it was frustrating is stating the obvious because we put so much into the game. We didn’t deserve to lose that game, in my opinion we deserved to win it,” he said.“But we didn’t punish Motherwell in the first half when we were on top and paid the price for a bad decision in our own penalty box.“The big manis honest enough to put his hands up because there was no need to go to ground. With the chances we had there were also mistakes at the other end of the pitch.“There were plenty positives to take from the way we played.“It’s just about getting that decision-making a bit better.“Overall, I was pleased with the performance evenwe didn’t get the result we deserved.“In our position we need points so you have to make better decisions and convert the pressure into points. But that’s the way I want my teams to play.”

title: official neil lennon leaves hibs
story: Neil Lennon has officially left his post as Hibernian head coach five days after being suspended, the Scottish Premiership club have confirmed.Lennon, , was removed from his duties on Friday place to allow an internal review, was lted by the club as part of this agreement.#Despite widespread speculation, the club confirms that neither Neil nor Garry has been guilty of any misconduct or wrongdoing and no disciplinary process has been commenced.#However, Neil, Garry and the club now consider that it would be in the best interests of all parties to part amicably.The club would like to place on notice its thanks to both Neil and Garry for their hard work and the success they have brought the club.#Neil and Garry would like to thank the club for having faith in them when they were appointed in  and for their support over two and a half years.#They would like to thank their players for their hard work and dedication and finally, the fans for their loyalty and support over their story: Scott Allardice has left Dundee United after nine years.The Dundonian came up through the club#s youth ranks but has struggled to break into the first team, making six league appearances.Allardice, , spent time on loan at East Fe last season and Dunfermline this term.A club statement said the midfielder-cum-defender has left the club #after both parties mutually agreed to end his contract.#Allardice said: “I#d like to thank everyone at Dundee United for the past nine years with a special thanks to all the academy coaches I worked with.#Ideally, the last  months would have gone better, but it is the right time to move on to a new, fresh challenge where.#I wish the club all the best for the rest of the season.”

title: tom duthie dundee united need to start performing in the big games
story: Despite the major disappointment of the defeat at Ayr United, the consolation for Dundee United fans at the moment has to be the fact they have become genuine promotion contenders under Robbie Neilson.The gap to the top of the table has stretched to six points again because of that Friday night loss at Somerset Park coupled with Ross County’s victory over Alloa on Saturday afternoon.It can’t be forgotten United’s poor goal dference effectively means right now the gap to the top is seven points.With just  games to go, time is also running out for United to make up the lost ground and clinch promotion at the first time of asking.Boosted by the January signings that are set to continue in the final few days of the window,they can gel quickly enough, Neilson will believe the deficit can by clawed back and, in a Championship race that’s seen every team drop points regularly, even a decent winning run could do that.The manager’s overall record since he arrived in October does also give some reason for Arabs not to give up hope just yet.Since his debut win at Partick Thistle in mid-October, with , his team are the leading points gatherers in the second tier.By beating Alloa in Dingwall on Saturday, County took their points tally over the same period to  and while no one would argue the fact promoted Ayr are having an excellent first campaign back at this level, they have been showing signs of running out of steam.Between their hugely impressive - win at Tannadice right at the end of November and their repeat success over United the other night, Ian McCall’s team had gone five league games without a win and also, of course, suffered that humiliating Scottish Cup exit at the hands of juniors Auchinleck Talbot.If that, and the points tally under the new manager, provides encouragement, what continues to be a major concern for United is their poor record against the others at the top end of the table.Friday was their fth clash with the top two on league business and, to date, the record reads played five, lost four, won one, score two and conceded .Add to that a League Cup loss up at County in July and what you have is a worrying statistic.Without wishing to paint an even darker picture, they have also only drawn two clashes with Inverness with both coming when the Highlanders were sitting in one of the promotion play-off places.If they are to realise American owner Mark Ogren’s dream of going up automatically during his first months in charge, it’s a statement of the obvious to say the big-game record has to improve drastically.Should it, United can still get to where they want to be. They’ve two games to come against County and one final crack at Ayr and, of those showdowns, two are at Tannadice.Yes, the two heaviest defeats of the season came there against County and Ayr but under Neilson that second defeat was the only one he’s suffered in seven home games so far.And last time he sent out a team to face County he did mastermind what was without doubt the best win of the campaign to date, a gritty - success on their patch, in November.If the manager can mould his rebuilt team over the next few weeks, wins like that one can be repeated.They’ll have to be, or United’s big-game failures will see them negotiating even more vital outings in the play-offs.
