story: Work will begin on Monday th February to install safety barriers and traffic management schemes to narrow lanes, with operations being carried out overnight between .pm and .am.Map: Transport ScotlandComplete overnight closures will be put in place from Friday nd to Monday th February : to : each night, with vehicles erted northwards via the A   A   A.This will continue for two weeks, and is likely to affect overnight journeys and deliveries to Inverness, with some drivers fearing  minutes could be added to journeys. Transport Scotland is urging road users to allow extra time for their journey.:Man killed in Christmas Day crash on A near PerthThe A is one of Scotlands major traffic arteriesEfforts will then turn to the full dualling scheme, which will be undertaken beside the A with one lane of traffic still moving in each directionSigned ersions will be put in place via the A for northbound traffic and via the A Dunkeld junction for southbound traffic.Access for residents living in Luncarty, Bankfoot and Stanley will be maintained throughout the four-night shut down via a local road.Gemma Montrose, project manager for Transport Scotland, said: ldquoThese traffic restrictions are a tried and tested approach that improve safety for road users and construction workers during what will be an extremely busy construction period.ldquoRoad safety is our first priority and we would like to take this opportunity to thank road users for their patience while we deliver these signicant improvement works to dual the A.:Free Church ministers call for Aupgradeas matter of urgencyMuch of the A is limited to single lanesInspector Davie Hynd from Police Scotland said: ldquoThe reduced speed limit is necessary to ensure that drivers are able to cope safely with the inevitable effects of the roadworks such as narrowed lanes contraflows and construction traffic."We would encourage road users to plan their journey in advance and leave extra time to travel through the works area.The A Dualling project is one of Scotlands largest ever transport infrastructure programmes. We are dealing with internationally environmentally designated sites rock cuttings building new bridges and widening existing major bridges public utilities dealing with the close proximity of the Highland Mainline Railway and there are currently over  junctions that must be incorporated to provide access to adjacent property and communities."Some very complex and demanding challenges lie ahead but, given our track record on other major projects, we are confident of delivery on time and on budget."

title: Rosemary Goring  Let  39 s enjoy this new chapter in the story of bookshops
story: Bookshops offered similar opportunities, except, of course, you had to pay for the pleasure they offered. I still have many of the books I bought with pocket money when I was young, carried through le like a lucky charm. TS Eliotrsquos Prufrock may have measured out his le with coffee spoons I have measured out mine with Puffins and King Penguins, Peregrines and Pelicans. If pressed, I could tell where I found each one.Like radio, the demise of the book has been often foretold. Books, we were unreliably informed, were yesterdayrsquos technology, so th century, so redundant in a digital age. I well recall the gleeful obituaries. The internet would sweep them away with tsunami-like ferocity. Kindles, apparently, were the future, and even I owned one once. Who knows where it lies unloved now. And who cares Similar prophesies of doom were made about bookshops, for what need was there for themno one wanted books  And for a while things did look a bit glum. With the demise of the Net Book Agreement, which determined that books must be sold at their cover price, many privately-owned bookshops found they couldnrsquot compete with the discounts offered by supermarkets and chain stores. Inevitably, sadly, some went to the wall or sold out to more voracious competitors.Of late, however, in what has been the bleakest of midwinters for the high street, there are signs that reports of the death of the bookshop were premature. In the last couple of weeks, I have heard of two new bookshops opening in Edinburgh. And last Saturday evening, I attended a mini book festival in Linlithgow, organised by the local independent, Far From the Madding Crowd, which was very well-attended, a testimony to the loyalty and warmth the shop engenders.The best bookshops are like that. When one of them is threatened it is a cause for mourning and resentment and the raising of petitions. For me, a town without a bookshop is unworthy of the name, a place where civilisation is yet to reach, where culture must surely fail to thrive. I have been in such outposts and nothing would drag me back.Where there is at least one bookshop there is hope. A year ago, I visited Christchurch in New Zealand, which is still struggling to recover from the devastating earthquakes of  and . The centre of the city was preternaturally quiet and the shopping mall was bereft of customers. But the one shop that was buzzing was Scorpio Books, also independently owned, which against all odds had managed to resurrect itself. Would the same, brave decision have been made by the fund managers who control chain stores  Perhaps. Then again, perhaps not.One of the new Edinburgh shops will be Toppingrsquos, which has a wonderful branch in St Andrews. The companyrsquos founder is Robert Topping, formerly of Waterstonersquos in Manchester, which he left after being told to limit the size of the stock. The story is told in a new memoir by Glasgow-born Sir Tim Waterstone, of whom I was briefly an employee ndash the least said about which the better. ldquoThe Waterstonersquos model, recalls Sir Tim, ldquowas simply this: the highest class of heavily stocked literary bookselling run on a national scale by an unusually enthusiastic and highly knowledgeable young staff.Waterstonersquos was born in  when the book trade was in dire of need of modernisation. Complacent, rival shops kept short hours and unsatisfying stock, and their staff were more inclined to turn custom away than welcome it. Waterstonersquos ndash which was in the vanguard of Sunday opening ndash initiated a bookselling revolution and played an intrinsic role in making the literary novel cool. In the store in which I worked, on any given night you might catch a reading by Gore Vidal, Richard Ford, Raymond Carver or Edna OrsquoBrien. It was like a club of which anyone could become a member.Scratch any writer and they will regale you with tales of their favourite bookshops. I have one ndash Main Street Trading in St Boswells ndash a handful of miles from where I live in the Borders. Some prefer charity shops, others, such as my biblioholic husband, emporia like the Strand in New York with its eight miles of books. In Browse: The World in Bookshops, Ali Smith hymns Leakeyrsquos second-hand bookshop in Inverness in which I always try and spend an hour or two when Irsquom in the vicinity. As she says, the books are what most matter, but it also has a log-burner, a cafe and an unique atmosphere. Moreover, it has to be one of the Highland capitalrsquos ldquomain attractions.Read more: Rosemary Goring on why Romain Gary was the most compelling new author she encountered last year

title: bumper-find-east-of-aberdeen-generates-excitement-in-oil-and-gas-industry
story: Read more: Success for oil firms underlines potential of mature area off ScotlandTotal made a find that is estimated to contain  million barrels recoverable with a well drilled with Chinarsquos CNOOC and Edison of Italy.Experts said the find may be the biggest made on the Uniited Kingdom Continental Shelf for more than a decade.The success comes after Total made a major gas discovery West of Shetland with the Glendronach well in September. This stoked excitement about the potential of the relatively under-explored waters off Shetland, which is still considered to be a frontier area.The Glengorm find has provided a reminder that there are still big finds to be made in areas of the North Sea in which there has been much more drilling over the years.Read more: French giants success could encourage oil and gas firms to explore in UK watersIt will boost hopes that exploration activity may recover after falling to record lows in the wake of the crude price plunge which took a heavy toll on the UK North Sea.ldquoThere is a lot of hype around frontier areas like West of Shetland, where Total discovered the Glendronach field last year, noted Kevin Swann at oil and gas consultancy Wood Mackenzie. ldquoBut Glengorm is in in the Central North Sea and this find shows there is still le in some of the more mature UK waters.Noting that Glengorm looked to be the largest gas discovery in the UK since Culzean in , Mr Swann said the strike represented a good start to what could prove to be a pivotal year for UK exploration. Oil and gas firms plan to drill several potentially high impact wells this year.Trade body Oil  Gas UK said Glengorm was a major milestone towards adding another generation of productive le to the UK North Sea and provided a great example of firms collaborating to unlock its potential.Glengorm was found in the kind of high pressure high temperature zone that can pose production challenges.However, the field lies relatively close to existing production facilities which it could be connected to, including the Elgin Franklin field operated by Total.ldquoOur strong position in the region will enable us to leverage existing infrastructures nearby and optimize the development of this discovery, noted Kevin McLachlan, senior vice president exploration at the French oil giant.He added: ldquoGlengorm is an achievement that demonstrates our capacity to create value in a mature environment thanks to our in-depth understanding of the basin.Read more: North Sea oil and gas industry to generate poundbn surplusThe well was operated by state-owned CNOOC. The China National Offshore Oil Corporation established a big position in the UK North Sea through the bn acquisition of Canadarsquos Nexen in . It operates the giant Buzzard and Golden Eagle fields and is one of the biggest oil producers in the UK.Executive vice president Xie Yuhong said Glengorm demonstrated the great exploration potential of the exploration licence it was found on. The company is looking forward to doing appraisal work on the find.On its website CNOOC describes the UK as a key production area with signicant room for growth. It employs around  people in the country.Edison has interests in a range of producing North Sea fields and exploration licences. The company says it will continue to build its UK portfolio through farm-ins and future licensing rounds.The Oil  Gas Authority said with between  and  billion barrels to be recovered on the UKCS there is every chance of yet more signicant finds being made. It noted only seven exploration wells were drilled in .CNOOC has a  per cent interest in the licence containing Glengorm, with Total and Edison on % each.Total acquired its interest in the licence through the pound.bn takeover of Maersk Oil in .

title: brexit-deal-explained-what-happens-now
story: Theresa May vowed to seek "legally binding" changes to the Withdrawal Agreement with the European Union, but gave no firm date for ing to Brussels to reopen negotiations.Mrs May told MPs on Tuesday night that while there was "limited appetite" to amend the deal, the House of Commons had "made it clear what it needs to approve a withdrawal agreement".Read more:Theresa May toto Brussels in bid to scrap Irish backstopKey figures in Brussels roundly rejected the PMs suggestion, as Donald Tusk insisted that the Withdrawal Agreement struck last November was not open for renegotiation. Meanwhile, the European Parliaments chief Brexit negotiator, Guy Verhofstadt, said there was "no majority to re-open or dilute" the agreement.Jeremy Corbyn, who boycotted cross-party talks after the Commons rejected the Withdrawal Agreement by a record  votes on January , said that he was now ready to meet the Prime Minister to discuss a "sensible Brexit solution that works for the whole country".He called on Mrs May to "face the reality that no-deal is not an option".This option became less likely after MPs rejected two proposals to delay Brexit by extending the two-year Article  negotiation processMrs May was unable to secure an acceptable agreement by February .It still remains unclear. The EU would have to signicantly change their stance on reopening the Withdrawal Agreementlegally-binding changes are to be made on the Irish backstop.But while the UK and EU remain at loggerheads over the issue, one of Mrs Mays key negotiating weapons was ripped from her hands by MPs when they voted on Tuesday evening to block a no-deal.

title: snp-minister-apologises-after-plugging-speech-by-blogger-with-abhorrent-views
story: Maree Todd, minister for children and young people, shared information about an upcoming event featuring Jason Michael McCann in Alness, and marked herself as ldquointerested in attending on Facebook.Mr McCann, who is based in Dublin, has previously labelled the British state ldquoan oppressive anti-democratic regime and accused it of trying to ignite a war in Northern Ireland and Scotland.He recently tweeted: ldquoBritish soldiers ed to the streets of Northern Ireland. Good Friday Agreement now utterly defunct.ldquoWithout peace, as the rules of war have it, these British soldiers are now legitimate targets.In one blog, he wrote: ldquoWhen I see my fellow independentistas wearing the poppy I see a contradiction.ldquoThis bloodied weed is nothing short of lsquoBritain the brandrsquo painted over the bones of its victims, and we Scots have given it enough.ldquoYet, my anger is not with those who wear it to remember. My frustration is that still there are people who fail to see how it is being used ndash with massive cultural force ndash to forge a sense of national unity in a state that is anything but one nation.ldquoIt is being used by the British state and by the nationalist foot soldiers of British thuggery as a nation building tool much in the same way a dog marks its territory ndash all over its victims in Flanders, France, Ireland, India, and all over Africa.Elsewhere, he wrote: "Brexit is not only the end of the Good Friday Agreement, it is the beginning of a war that will be fought in England."He has also suggested unionist politicians and media outlets are the ldquoscum of the Earth.Ms Todd apologised for retweeting information about Mr McCannrsquos upcoming Alness speech, which described him as a ldquogreat speaker with an important message.She told the Daily Mail, which highlighted his views: ldquoI was not aware of the, frankly, abhorrent views held by this inidual and was horried when they were pointed out to me.ldquoObviously I am sorry for having retweeted this event.She added: ldquoAs soon as I was made aware, I contacted the organisers to share with them his views. They have, rightly, moved to cancel the event.Mr McCann told the newspaper he stood by his comments.He said: ldquoIrsquom a pacist and a devout Christian and I donrsquot want Ireland toto violence.ldquoThe target comment comes from the Green Book issued to Provisional IRA volunteers. Itrsquos a quote from the book.Last year, Ms Todd was criticised after promoting a sugar-packed tablet recipe days after the Scottish Government announced a crackdown on sugary foods.The Scottish Tories said many SNP politicians follow Mr McCannrsquos posts on social media, and called on Nicola Sturgeon to ldquosever links between the party and the blogger.Tory MSP Edward Mountain, an army veteran, said: ldquoThese views are utterly abhorrent and cannot be excused by the SNP because of his belief in Scottish independence.Scottish Liberal Democrat MSPAlex Cole-Hamilton said people would wonder why Ms Todd was"sharing details of a speaker she now claims to know nothing about".An SNP spokesman said: ldquoMaree Todd condemned this inidualrsquos views as soon as they were brought to her attention ndash and he is not an party member.ldquoButthe Tories are intent on trawling peoplersquos Twitter followers they had better make sure their own house is in order.ldquoThe SNPrsquos priority this week is passing a budget to provide extra cash for schools, hospitals and other services, providing some stability amid ongoing Brexit chaos ndash something the Tories just want to ert attention from.Mr McCann is currently on a speaking tour of Scotland, starting with an event at Airdrie and culminating in Stirling.

title: david-mundell-brexit-vote-sent-strong-and-clear-message-to-the-eu
story: Speaking to ITV he defended the Governments stance and his voting on changing the Withdrawal Agreement, which previously he said could not be changed.:Brexit latest: Theresa May toto Brussels in bid to scrap Irish backstopWhen askedhe was right about whether the backstop could change or not, he said: "What I said is it was quite clear that the backstop in the agreement was the issue that made MPs reject it overwhelmingly.WATCH: Scottish Secretary @DavidMundellDCT tells us tonights #Brexit vote sends a strong message to the EU. pic tLhyay"After tonights vote, its very clear thatthe backstop was changed, and the Prime Minister didnt duck the challenge of that, that we would be capable of getting a majority in Parliament."I think the message to the EU was very clear two weeks ago, that the agreement as is will not get a majority in Parliament.":Donald Tusk - Withdrawal Agreement is "not open for renegotiation"David Mundell had previously said that the backstop could not be changed and was quizzed as to why he had decided to vote with the Government on attempting to change the backstop.Mr Mundell stated that circumstances in the last two weeks and a defeat in the House of Commons had forced the Government to change.He said: "We lost by  votes, it was clear that the agreement as it was, as it is, will not command a majority in Parliament."If we are to get an agreement through, and I believe the EU want an agreement, I believe they want an orderly Brexit just as we do, then a change will have to be made to get a majority in Parliament."There is a majority,  MPs said that they would back an agreementthere was a change to the backstop.When quizzed on previous comments Mr Mundell had made about the EU not wanting to reopen the agreement as it couldnt be changed, Mr Mundell said: "I dont think the EU wants to reopen the agreement but we all have to face up to the facts, and the facts are that there is not a majority in the House of Commons for that agreement."What tonight had indicated is that there is a potentially a majority for an agreement with a revisal to the backstop."Following the vote last night, there was no immediate announcement of any plan for Mrs May to visit Brussels, where MEPs were due to debate Brexit after an address from European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker.:The UK has lost its senses over Brexit, but science can tell us whyMr Juncker met the European commissioners on Wednesday morning to discuss new plans for dealing with a no-deal Brexit, said a spokesman.A spokesman for European Council president Donald Tusk announced that he will speak by phone with Mrs May on Wednesday evening.Following Tuesday nights votes in the House of Commons, Mr Tusks spokesman said: "The Withdrawal Agreement is and remains the best and only way to ensure an orderly withdrawal of the UK from the European Union."The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."Brussels chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier told reporters that the EUs position was "very clear", while Irish foreign minister Simon Coveney said the backstop remained "necessary" and French President Emmanual Macron said the Withdrawal Agreement was "not renegotiable".The European Parliaments chief Brexit negotiator, Guy Verhofstadt, said there was "no majority to re-open or dilute" the Withdrawal Agreement.

title: brexit-theresa-may-faces-backlash-from-brussels-over-withdrawal-agreement-renegotiation
story: The Prime Minister succeeded in uniting her party behind a plan to rewrite the deal to address concerns about the Irish backstop.But senior figures in Brussels, Berlin, Paris and Dublin resisted the demand from Mrs May as the clock ticks down to the UKs departure from the European Union on March .The Prime Minister also clashed with Jeremy Corbyn in the Commons ahead of private talks with the Labour leader on the Brexit process.Having boycotted earlier cross-party talks, the Labour leader said he was ready to discuss a "sensible" approach to Brexit after MPs voted on Tuesday night to rule out no deal.Mr Corbyn demanded to know which of her red lines she was prepared to compromise on in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit."It really is time that the Prime Minister acknowledged she has got to move on from the red lines she put down in the first place," he said.:Theresa May accused of presiding over a rising tide of racism in the UKBut Mrs May told Mr Corbyn he had opposed "every move by this Government to get a deal" and "he is the one risking no deal".In dramatic scenes on Tuesday night, MPs voted by a margin of  to  to back a plan - the "Brady amendment" - which requires the PM to replace the Agreements controversial backstop with "alternative arrangements" to keep the Irish border open after Brexit.But asked five times on BBC Radio s Today programme what this "alternative" involved, Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay was unable to provide any specic explanation.Mr Barclay said the UK was "exploring in terms of the use of technology... looking at things like the time limit" to deal with the backstop.He added: "There are a number of options, there are issues in terms of having time limits, issues in terms of exit clauses, issues in terms of technology, and this will be the nature of the negotiation with the European Union in the coming days.":PMQs: Theresa May claims Jeremy Corbyn is risking a no-deal BrexitDowning Street has suggested that the UKs position could involve a time-limit or exit clause to the backstop or swapping it for a free trade agreement, as proposed in the so-called Malthouse Compromise drawn up by MPs from the Tories Remain and Leave wings.But the suggestion that the deal struck between the Government and Brussels could be unpicked was rejected by senior figures across the EU.European Council president Donald Tusk will speak by phone with Mrs May on Wednesday evening.Following Tuesday nights votes in the House of Commons, Mr Tusks spokesman said: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for renegotiation."Brussels chief Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, told reporters that the EUs position was "very clear", while Irish foreign minister Simon Coveney said the backstop remained "necessary". French President Emmanuel Macron said the Withdrawal Agreement was "not renegotiable".European Commission vice-president Frans Timmermans said there was "an increasing risk" that the UK will leave without a deal in March."We continue to urge the UK Government to clary its intentions with respect to its next steps as soon as possible," he added.The European Parliaments chief Brexit negotiator, Guy Verhofstadt, expressed frustration with the British: "What needs to stop is this: An amendment with  votes for, then an amendment with  votes against, an amendment that barely pulls through, one that fails... That is no way to build a future relationship with the EU.":Ian Blackford: Calls for permission to hold Indyref must be accepted by UK GovernmentGermanys foreign minister, Heiko Maas, said: "Germany and the entire Union are firmly on Irelands side. We will not allow Ireland to be isolated on this issue."French Europe minister Nathalie Loiseau said: "The Withdrawal Agreement that is on the table is the best possible agreement. Let us not reopen it."Mr Barclay claimed that Tuesday nights amendments, two weeks after Mrs May suffered the heaviest parliamentary defeat in modern history over the meaningful vote, had "overturned a defeat of  into a victory".But there was concern from the business community, with CBI director general Carolyn Fairbairn describing the Brady amendment as "a throw of the dice" and warning that firms were having to accelerate expensive no-deal preparations.Brexiteer ringleader Jacob Rees-Mogg made clear on Wednesday that he remains prepared to see the UK leave without a deal on March the EU refuses to reopen negotiations."Ifthink the Withdrawal Agreement is non-negotiable then we will have to leave without an agreement," he told TalkRadio. "Do they want the pound billion, do they want an agreement... or us just to leave  Its up to them."

title: pmqs-sketch-maybot-and-highlander-clash-over-blackfords-reckless-remarks
story: The context was the hangover from the Brexit party on Tuesday evening when a ldquoflabberghasted SNP leader lashed out at the Conservative Government for having successfully pushed the move through Parliament to try to scrap the Irish backstop.To uproar from the Tory benches, Ian Blackford declared: ldquoThe Conservative Party has effectively ripped apart the Good Friday Agreement. This House should be ashamed of itself.Among those honourable members incensed by the SNP chiefrsquos accusation was the DUPrsquos Nigel Dodds, who jumped up to denounce the Nationalistrsquos ldquoutterly reckless remarks.David Mundell, the Scottish Secretary, later went on the telly to accuse Mr B of ldquocontemptible behaviour, saying using Northern Ireland in this way was ldquojust another tool in the SNPrsquos armoury of securing a second independence referendum.At PMQs, after the usual Brexit ding-dong between the PM and the chief comrade, the Highlander rose to a rumble of leftover Conservative discontent from the night before to ask what were the ldquoalternative arrangements to the backstop the Maybot was proposing.Theresa May explained something had to change given the historic -majority rejection of her original plan but she also keen to comment on the SNP chiefrsquos reference to the GFA, which she declared was ldquofrankly irresponsible.The Highlander rose to insist, faced with a wall of Conservative noise, that the only thing irresponsible was Mrs Mrsquos actions. His SNP chums were gesticulating to the Speaker about the level of baying from the Tory benches.John Bercow jumped up to intervene. ldquoAttempts to shout him down are not just rude, they are irresponsible and undemocratichellipStop it! It is low grade, it is useless and it will not work, declared the Speaker.Mr B attempted to continue, accusing the PM of making a ldquograceless response and claiming: ldquoWhat she demonstrated in that answer was: lsquoHere are my principles. If you donrsquot like them, you can have some more.rsquoHe tried to continue as the Conservative berserkersrsquo wall of sound intensied. The Speaker again jumped up to snap: ldquoStop it! Chanting in the background is utterly irresponsible.The Highlander continued to make sure he got his soundbite in: ldquoDoes the Prime Minister accept that she promised Scotland everything but delivered nothing To Tory cheers, the PM hit back, boasting: ldquoScotland is part of the United Kingdom, and noting how figures just out showed over  per cent of Scotlandrsquos ldquoexports went to the rest of the UK, which was more than three times more than those to the EU. So there.Raising SNP hackles, the Maybot had the last word, noting how Mr B represented a party that wanted to erect a border between Scotland and England.ldquoThe biggest threat to the future of Scotland, snapped the PM to a mixture of Tory cheers and Nationalist jeers, ldquois sitting on the SNP benches.

title: remembering-michael-mick-mcgahey-former-vice-president-of-the-national-union-of-mineworkers
story: Michael "Mick" McGahey, who was also Scottish president of the NUM, was born in Shotts, North Lanarkshire, in  and started working in the mines immediately after leaving school at the age of .In a speech given in  to the STUC, Mr McGahey made the case for devolution and is credited as having played a key role in the decision to create the Scottish Parliament.But Mr McGahey never saw the Parliament in Edinburgh open on May ,  as he died aged  on January  of that year.His ashes were buried within the foundations of the Parliament.His family joined former Scottish miners and MSPs outside Holyrood on Wednesday to lay a wreath honouring his letimes work.Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard said: "It was an honour to mark the th anniversary of the death of Mick McGahey, whose ashes are buried in the foundations of the Scottish Parliament."Micks defence of the working class and trade unions continues to inspire."Several Scottish Labour MSPs paid tribute to the legacy of Mr McGahey on Twitter after attending the ceremony.Alex Rowley wrote: "Honoured to take part in a wreath-laying ceremony with the family of Mick McGahey outside the Scottish Parliament today."His ashes are buried under the Debating Chamber of the Scottish Parliament and shows his testament to delivering a Scottish Parliament and fighting for his class."Labour MSP for Lothians Neil Findlay wrote: "Delighted to host NUM legend Michael McGaheys family, friends and comrades today to lay wreaths at the Scottish Parliament on the th anniversary of his death - Michael was instrumental in getting the STUC to support the plan to establish a Scottish Parliament."There have been calls to create a national memorial in the Scottish Parliament in tribute to those who worked in the mines.A Scottish Government spokesman said any proposals for such a memorial would be a matter for the Scottish Parliament.Pat Egan, a former miner in Scotland, described Mr McGahey as an "inspirational leader" and praised his decision to take a stand on issues that were not always popular during his time."He was an exceptional leader and had anart of bringing people together. Its important that his role is remembered," said Mr Egan."Mick will be remembered by the miners as a pillar of working-class communities in Scotland, and we want to see that his legacy, and the legacy of the mining communities, lives on."

title: victory-for-jeremy-corbyn-backed-campaign-to-save-one-of-edinburghs-historic-streets
story: The proposed development at Steadrsquos Place has been refused by the city planning committee.The decision was welcomed by the Save Leith Walk campaign which said: "We have a vision for Leith, for community led development, meeting local housing needs, supporting small business, today we are a step closer to achieving that."Thank you to everyone who has supported us. A win for communities across Scotland."The Save Leith Walk campaign was launched to fight plans for a pound million redevelopment which the group says ignores the historical signicance of the street.The campaigners were celebrating in September, when yhe city council "finally" accepted their "stop the demolition" petitions.The campaign was formed by concerned residents who say Drum Property Grouprsquos plans were not in keeping with the surrounding culture and heritage of the area.They say the sandstone frontage is an "iconic part" of Leith Walk that many want to see kept.The developer wanted to build a facility incorporating a -bed student accommodation, -bedroom hotel,  affordable homes, a restaurant, cafeacute and retail units.Campaigners were fighting to preserve the sandstone frontage on Leith Walk which will be bulldozeredthe plans go ahead.More than , have signed shypetitions and over , have written personal letters and lodged formal objections to the developerrsquos plans.The land was purchased by Drum in  with the city council earmarking the site for development since .In its submission Drum said while the frontage to Leith Walk site falls within the boundaries of Leith Walk Town Centre and the Leith Conservation Area, Historic Environment Scotland said it did not meet the criteria for listing.In response to the decision, the campaign group added. It is proof thatyou organise and engage with local people,you stay positive and refuse to give up, then you can have a say in how your area is developed.Rarely has Leithrsquos motto lsquoperseverersquo been more appropriate.ldquoWe would like to thank the councillors at todayrsquos meeting for listening to the people who elected them, opposing the demolition and recognising that the proposed development was wholly inappropriate for this site.ldquoWe thank the many thousands of people who have supported this campaign, turned up to public meetings, workshops, bought T-shirts, lodged objections, signed petitions and shared ideas. Your voices have been heard.ldquoThis campaign has secured cross-party support and we would like to thank our local MSP, councillors and community councils and who have been steadfast in their objection to the proposed demolition and development at every step of the way."Graeme Bone, group managing director of Drum, said before the plans went to the council: ldquoFor the past eighteen months, we have worked closely with the council, the local community and many groups, businesses and organisations to address the urgent need to bring new investment, connectivity and le back to this hugely important part of Leith Walk and the wider Pilrig area.ldquoGiven there are no valid planning reasons to oppose the proposals, we trust that the elected members will now share the view of their officers and give the green light to this major transformational investment opportunity for Leith Walk and the rest of the city.

title: bins to be collected once every three weeks in new council strategy
story: Aberdeenshire residents will be encouraged to become recycling champions with the introduction of a controversial three-weekly collection programme.The revised waste strategy for all , properties in the Shire was approved in a - vote by the council’s Infrastructure Services Committee despite an alternative option from Peterhead SNP councillor Stephen Smith who said it was “too much, too soon”.From April next year, households will have weekly kerbside collections for one of three bins including a  litre bin for paper and card and  litre bin for metals, plastics and cartons.However under the new scheme, the existing general residual bin for non-recyclable waste will be signicantly reduced to a  litre capacity.Councillors were told by waste director Philip McKay that while it was a considerable reduction, the service felt it “should be manageable for most households”.He added that while a three-weekly non-recyclable waste collection might feel a bit daunting to residents initially – as did the move from weekly to fortnightly collections in Aberdeenshire a few years ago – experience from other Scottish local authorities showed that it is workable and can lead to a signicant increase in recycling rates.Mr McKay also stressed that given the larger recycling capacity provided in the favoured option, it provided “more flexibility in the future” for the addition of other recyclable materials without the need for additional recycling containers.Councillors were told that the scheme had the potential to save waste services £, per year at the lower end of the scale and even morethere was a higher uptake in recycling.However, Peterhead councillor Stephen Smith said the proposals as they stood were a step too far for North-east communities.In a bid to address concerns about the potential impact of any necessary changes to the waste strategy, he proposed that instead of using a -litre bin for three weekly collections, Aberdeenshire Council instead do what has happened in much of the rest of Scotland and keep the  litre bin for three weekly waste collections, with new  litre bins – which are expected to be funded in large part by ‘Zero Waste Scotland’ – being used for paper and card recycling for a transitional period.Councillor Smith’s proposal – which he claimed would have saved an estimated £, annually – followed confirmation from council officers that such a proposal would be compatible with Zero Waste Scotland’s requirements for helping to fund the cost of the new bins required.But council depute leader Peter Argyle warned against “changing title: farmers invited to free quality meat scotland meeting
story: Aberdeenshire farmers looking to optimise the performance of their grazing livestock by developing their knowledge of their stock#s mineral requirements are invited to attend a free meeting being organised by Quality Meat Scotlandas part of its Better Grazing programme.The event, which will be held at Thainstone Centre on Wednesday, February  will focus on the role and sources of minerals, symptoms of deficiency and negative effects on production.The workshop, which is one of five being held around Scotland next month, will also describe the types of tests and analysis available, how to interpret the results, and how farmers can work with their vet or nutritionist to develop action plans and treatment options.Livestock vet Fiona Lovatt and ruminant mineral nutritionist Peter Bone will be the key speakers at this meeting and will help advise the farmers who attend how they can optimise livestock performance by managing the minerals of their stock at pasture.“Cattle and sheep require certain key minerals for both reproduction and growth without them the animal’s productivity and profitability can be affected,” said Dr Lovatt, who runs the sheep veterinary consultancy business, Flock Health Ltd.She added: “With many livestock producers looking to reduce supplementary feed costs and make the most from their grazed grass, having a good awareness of the mineral requirements of their stock at pasture is vital.“The hands-on workshop in Inverurie will help address the challenges that sheep and cattle farmers face when trying to ensure correct mineral balance in their livestock – so there is enough but not too much!”Delivering the event with Fiona will be Peter Bone, who has over  years of experience working as a ruminant mineral nutritionist in the UK, Ireland, America, Mexico and New Zealand. In  he established his own consultancy business to focus on ruminant mineral nutrition working alongside veterinary practices and livestock farmers.“The correct balance of minerals is important and knowing all the sources of minerals on farm is a key element of maximising livestock performance from grazed grass,” said Mr Bone.Emily Grant, Knowledge Transfer Specialist with QMS commented: “I’m delighted that we have Fiona and Peter coming to speak at the Inverurie Better Grazing meeting.“Minerals play an important role in livestock production, but it’s not an exact science. A shortage, and in some cases an excess of minerals can have a negative effect on production. Supply from pasture can also y through the season, as can livestock requirements.She added: “Fiona and Peter are both enthusiastic and engaging presenters with a great reputation of being able to communicate complex issues in an easily understandable way. I would urge farmers looking to gain a little more insight in to minerals, and how to make the most of them, to attend this meeting.”Now its third year, the main objective of the QMS Better Grazing Groups is to improve livestock producers’ profitability through the better use of grazed grass.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Sandy Reid with PC Laura Fairbairn and PD Ava"  North East Dog Unit celebrates th anniversary viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"The free “Better Grazing” meeting will begin at am and finish at pm and lunch will be provided.Places at this meeting can be reserved on the Eventbrite booking website, or by contacting QMS direct on    or emailing info@qmscotland.

title: house plan approved at oldmeldrum
story: The future of Oldmeldrum Golf Club has been secured thanks to councillors at the Formartine Area Committee.Plans to build a single house on land at the golf course went before councillors on Tuesday, January .The site in question is located directly behind an existing house next to the A and A junction.It is currently used for turf growing, but it had been classed as “obsolete” as it is cheaper for the Golf Club to buy new turfcompared to the man hours needed to maintain and cut their own.The planning application received a total of  representations, all of which were in support of the idea.However in a report put to councillors ahead of the meeting, council planners recommended that the plan be refused as the land had never been developed, and that the development itself was contrary to policy in the Aberdeenshire Local Development Plan.Speaking at the meeting on behalf of the club, Patricia Ramsay said that it is currently facing financial dficulties and the debt that it has is preventing the club from moving forward.She added: “The sale of this unused piece of land is the only way of raising much needed funds.“This would be a leline to this community asset.”After discussing the plan, councillor Paul Johnston suggested that the plans be approved with a delegated grant, and his decision was backed by councillor Karen Adam.Cllr Johnston said: “We have to think about the public circumstances, this is a private club but should it have to wind up, that would have a knock-on effect in the local community.”The proposal went to a vote and seven councillors backed the plan with just one vote against it.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: ice cream parlour to go orange for charity
story: Mackie#s of Scotland will colour their most popular flavour, known as #Traditional#, bright orange on Friday, February , to raise awareness and money for charity.Mackie’s ., their Aberdeen ice cream parlour, will be a bright vision with orange lighting, balloons and staff dressed in orange T-shirts for Muscular Dystrophy UK.Even the company’s logo will be converted to an orange spotted cow for the day. Alongside the orange Traditional ice cream, a parlour cabinet will be filled with over  orange tubs, each containing one of nine dferent prizes, from £ gt vouchers, to chocolate bars, so that customers can take part in a fundraising lucky dip.Mackie’s Marketing Director, Karin Hayhow said: “Muscular Dystrophy UK is a charity close to our hearts because we have experienced first-hand the severity of the illness.“We hope that our parlour customers have fun with the orange lucky dip infor a donation towards the work of Muscular Dystrophy UK.”The company is getting behind the day as part of their long-running support for people with any type of muscular dystrophy in Scotland.Muscular Dystrophy UK is the official charity for Mackie’s of Scotland and the joint venture company, Mackie’s at Taypack who make Mackie’s potato crisps and other savoury snacks.The association is founded on the personal experience of both companies, as Denis Emslie who worked as the Sales Director at Mackie’s of Scotland for  years, and Mark Taylor - brother of George Taylor, Managing Director at Mackie’s at Taypack - both lost their lives to forms of MD.Scotland’s Muscular Dystrophy UK Regional Development Manager, Dean Widd said: “We are incredibly grateful to our wonderful corporate partners Mackie’s of Scotland. There are just over , people in Scotland with muscular dystrophy and the money raised through Go Orange for a Day helps to fund our work into new treatments and campaigns for better care and support for people with muscle wasting conditions to live as independently as possible.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The top selling item at the sale, a  DAF LF  Johnston V road sweeper"  Sale success at ThainstoneviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin"  Women urged to go for smear after uptake reaches all time low viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: inverurie play centre plans unveiled
story: Plans have been unveiled for a socially-inclusive soft play centre at an Inverurie industrial estate.Newly-formed charity ‘Because Everyone Counts’ wants to create the facility at a unit owned by Craigdon Mountain Sports at Burghmuir Circle.The group has been founded to provide a safe and inclusive play space for children from the local community from pre-school and nursery school age up to a maximum of  years.The applicants say the facility will be the first inclusive soft play centre within the North-east to offer adapted play to allow those with additional support needs to integrate with mainstream children.In a supporting statement to Aberdeenshire Council’s planning department, they say: “It will work together with local groups and schools such as St. Andrews offering somewhere safe to go.”A separate room will be available for children with limited communication and sensory disorders and will provide multi-sensory equipment.The facility would operate from .am to .pm seven days a week and the expected usage will be for a maximum of  children per day split into two-hour sessions.It is understood that special needs groups will arrive and be collected by mini-bus as will groups from local nurseries.If successful, the soft play centre would take up residence next to the Inverurie Gymnastics Club which also leases a unit.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: mackie s offers sweet take on burns night scran
story: Back by popular demand, Mackies of Scotland is relaunching its limited edition haggis and marmalade ice cream for Burns Night.The handcrafted speciality recipe – which has been made on the firms Westertown family farm – is available all weekend at Mackie’s . parlour in Aberdeen.The Burns Night treat will be available all weekendAt am this morning, piper Robert Reid from Deeside Caledonia Pipe Band piped the haggis ice cream in to the Marischal Square parlour.The ice cream has been made with Scotland’s famous Hall’s haggis, and has orange marmalade swirled through the mix.In celebration of Scotland’s Ploughman Poet, customers at . will be given free samples of the experimental dessert – and those who play a tune on the bagpipes will be able to enjoy any free scoop of their choice.Yvette Harrison, Parlour Manager at Mackie’s ., said: “While Marmalade is not a traditional accompaniment for Haggis – we added a ripple to help make this Scottish delicacy a little tastier when served cold in ice cream. And, of course a nip of whisky can also be drizzled over the top to raise a cone to the Bard.“Our haggis ice cream was such a hit last year that we just had to bring it back for Burns Night . Since last year’s limited edition batch, we’ve had people visit the parlour specically to try the flavour. So this weekend is the perfect opportunity for those who didn’t get the chance the first time round to satisfy their curiosity – and their taste buds.”Mackie’s is encouraging the public to share their thoughts on the creation with the hashtag #taemackiesicecream.Yvette added: “We love experimenting with our flavours at Mackie’s, and in celebration of Burns we’re challenging everyone to step outside their comfort zone, and try a scoop of our latest creation."data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Brian McKandie"  Pensioners injuries were "worst" Detective had ever seenviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Singer, radio and television presenter Aled Jones MBE will perform a live set at the event"  Charity to mark th anniversary with celebratory Ball viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: north east dog unit celebrates 60th anniversary
story: The North East Dog Unit in Aberdeen has celebrated its th anniversary by bringing together its latest recruits and the unit#s first ever handler.PC Sandy Reid and his dog PD Rennie were the founding members of the police dog unit in Aberdeen, and were first deployed in .Mr Reid, , visited the Dog Unit todayto gt Rennie’s original collar and name tag, and met with current members of the dog unit including recent recruits PC Laura Fairbairn and PD Ava to mark this signicant milestone.Sandy joined Aberdeen City Police in  when he was  years old. He worked ‘On the Beat’ for a few years and was then asked to set up the first dog unit in the area. He and Rennie were the sole members of the unit to start with but Sandy gradually built up a team of handlers and dogs.After setting up the dog unit Sandy went on to set up the Underwater Diving Unit for the Force and also the Specialist Policing Unit based at Aberdeen Airport. Sandy retired as a Sergeant in Bucksburn in .Speaking about the celebration Instructor PC Steve Warden said: “We are delighted to have Sandy back in the unit today to help us celebrate  years of the North East Dog Unit. Since founding the unit, there have been hundreds of dogs and handlers who have all worked hard to help keep people safe here in the North East. We are a very special unit and we assist operational colleagues on all manner of calls from locating missing people, searching for items such as weapons, evidence and drugs and helping control volatile or aggressive situations. “Despite the many changes in policing in the North East over the last  years, it is great that the dog unit has remained and developed. We have a very strong team with a mix of experience but with the same dedication to the unit and the job. We hope that the North East Dog Unit enjoys many more decades of work.” As part of the celebration, Mr Reid has donated Rennie’s original collar and dog tag which is engraved stating that Rennie was owned by the Chief Constable of Aberdeen City Police and has been framed as a lasting memento.Retired officer, Sandy Reid added: “I have kept in touch with the Unit since I retired more than  years ago and it was great to celebrate this milestone with them today. The current dog handlers face much of the same challenges I did. It is a ied and exciting job to have but the most special element is the unique bond which develops from working and training with your dog.”PC Laura Fairbairn has been a police officer for  years and recently completed her dog handler training at the Scottish Police Dog Training Centre. PD Ava is a two year old German Shepherd who was bred in the Czech Republic and sourced by the national dog unit last summer. Ava and Laura were paired up during Laura’s initial training and have been putting into practice what they have learned during their training.Speaking about her new role PC Fairbairn said: “I’m really pleased and excited to be part of the dog unit. It’s a unique team and very dferent to the roles I’ve held within the police so far. Ava and I are getting on great. She’s a really good dog and we’ve bonded really well. She’s a general purpose dog so we get called to tracking and tracing calls at the moment."Once we’ve developed our experience and expertise I’ll take on a second specialist dog such as a drugs or explosives dog. At the moment I’m just enjoying getting used to working in the unit and looking after and working with Ava."data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"BEAR Scotland"  Overnight resurfacing work to start on A viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: what is martial law and why might it be introduced after brexit
story: It could be introduced in the UK to try and stop any riots that break out after we leave the EU on March .But what is martial law and how does it work Martial law - officially called the Civil Contingencies Act - is the imposition of direct military control, to help deal with war, terrorism, or an emergency that threatens serious damage to human le or the environment. Martial law gives authorities a range of powers - they could stop public rallies, impose curfews, limit movement and travel, and confiscate or destroy property. The law also allows government to change other laws to protect people orthey need to make sure we have access to money, food, water and fuel supplies.The emergency regulations are usually only brought into force for a short period of time.Do you have any Brexit-related questions  Email gemma.jimmison@jpimediadata-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.carricktoday webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The guest speakers at Ayrshire Colleges Girls Into Construction and Civil Engineering day"  Girls learn about civil engineering jobsviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.carricktoday webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Will Brexit affect your travel plans "  Theres just  days to go - will Brexit affect your travel plans  viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "CARR | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "CARR | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeWednesday  Jan  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: christmas tree collection reminder
story: Orkney Islands Council is reminding folk that their Christmas tree collection service for households on the Orkney mainland, within mph areas only, will get underway from Monday next week.The limited collection for real trees will be carried between Monday and the following Friday, February .The intention is that trees collected will be recycled at the council’s Bossack waste facility, along with other garden waste left at recycling centres around Orkney, to produce a fine soil conditioner.Therefore anyone using the tree collection service is urged to take extra care that all tinsel and decorations are removed from their trees.The soil conditioner can be picked up free of charge, subject to availability, from the Council’s Household Waste and Recycling Centres at Bossack in Tankerness, and Hatston, in Kirkwall.Collections fall on normal refuse recycling collection days and will take place as follows:Area  — Kirkwall : Monday February Area  — East Holm, Deerness, pickup.Householders outwith the mph limits can visit their local Household Waste Recycling Centres at Hatston, Garson, Bossack, Cursiter Quarry, St Margaret’s Hope and Dounby during normal opening hours, where trees can be placed in the #green waste# skips.Opening hours are available on the council#s website, on the Civic Amenity Site page.Trees can also be trimmed, cut up and placed into the title: Bid for 60k funding as Dingwalls Puffin Pool limps along
story: AN urgent pound, fundraising campaign to enable essential repairs at an ailing hydrotherapy pool used by thousands of people suffering painful or disabling conditions has been launched.The charity-run Puffin Pool in Dingwall has been forced to close its doors on several occasions and is currently ldquolimping along, says its board which is urging people to support an appeal to keep it open.It provides specialist therapy to adults and children with conditions affecting their joints, bones, muscles or neurological system and is also used to help speed up rehabilitation after accidents and operations.But the pool has had to close several times due to the failure of the air handling unit.Board member Barbara Manson said it needed a major overhaul including a new ultra violet system for the water purication system and replacement entrance doors.ldquoIt is limping along until we can get new equipment, she said. ldquoItrsquos the fact the pool is  years old and everything is beginning to break down. We are also very aware there needs to be some internal structural alterations.Given the urgency, the board is using its capital reserves to order the new air handling unit which is should be installed in March.ldquoIf the equipment breaks down between now and then, the pool will have to close, Mrs Manson said. ldquoSome people attend the pool on a weekly basis and that is what keeps them going. If it has to close for a number of weeks, it can make a real dference to their mobility and pain control.Retired GP Helen Charley, board chairman, said:ldquoHaving been a GP in Cromarty for  years, and having needed both hips and knees replaced, I am all too aware of how vital the Puffin Pool is to the good health and wellbeing of so many patients like me, she said.Established in  by Dr Malcolm Stevens, the pool has provided an average , sessions each year over the past four years. They are supervised by qualied supervisors and leguards.The majority of income is from its charity shop In Tulloch Street and the fees which are kept affordable for those on benefits, pensions and low incomes although these have increased by  per cent.Supporters are rallying to support the appeal and staff plan a -mile sponsored walk from Tain to Dingwall.To donate, see www.puffinpool or pop in to the pool or shop.Wednesday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Bid to get folk behind Dingwall improvement project
story: BUSINESSES keen to help regenerate Ross-shirersquos county town are being asked to show their support by getting surveys paving the way for a new development project lodged within days.The Dingwall Means Business group is behind plans for a business improvement districtwhich could mirror the success of a similar scheme in Inverness.BID manager George Murray said the group was now ldquowell into its year of listening and talking to all businesses in and around Dingwall to promote a lsquoyesrsquo for BID for the town.He said: ldquoNearly  surveys have gone out and we are still looking for a few more to be ed. The success of the Dingwall BID depends upon our local businessesrsquo support.ldquoWe are working hard to gather information from all the businesses in Dingwall and we need to hear from everyone. This is your chance to have your say and add to the overall business plan. Then all you have to do is vote yes in the ballot and we can make these projects happen.ldquoWe really want to make sure that nobody is missed and that everyone gets their opportunity to vote because this could be a monumental time in our townrsquos history. This could become the year when Dingwall businesses take control over the townrsquos economic future.Mr Murray said: ldquoWe are aware that there must be a decenton their investment. I believe Highland Council currently collect a wee bit more than pound million per annum from non-domestic ratepayers and Irsquove calculated that the levy would need to be between . to three per cent.ldquoThis would allow us to invoice the council for approximately pound,. Itrsquos also possible we would be able to almost match fund this figure from other sources. This would be an amazing amount banked in Dingwall to be spent on Dingwall. This is how we would fund the five-year plan ready to start after a yes vote.He wants remaining surveys, seeking feedback from businesses to a number of questions, ed by Friday, February .Survey results will then be collated with a five-year business plan set to be drafted by the end of March. A yes no vote on BID would then be held in May.Gordon McIntosh, practice manager of Munro  Noble, is a director of BID Inverness and believes the scheme can pay idends for Dingwall too.He said ldquocoach ambassadors had brought more tourists into the city, increasing spend. It meant local businesses were stakeholders in any centre development plans and have the ability to lobby the council over issues of interest. The scheme also paved the way for successful events such as classic car shows, Easter egg hunts and bar and business awards.He said: ldquoWith representatives from a cross section of businesses on the board the strong advocacy we have provided has achieved some notable results. These results have been for the betterment of our business and social community. A healthier, connected community drives profit opportunities.Wednesday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies.
